div.head: To the right honourable, George Harding, baron Barkeley of Barkeley castle and knight of the order of the bat●e to the illustrious prince Charles.
div.p:
That I may present my excuse why, (Being a stranger to your lordship) I offer this poem to your patronage, I plead this warrant; men (Who never saw the sea, yet desire to behold that regiment of waters,) choose some eminent river, to guide them thither; and make that as it were, their conduct, or postilion: by the like ingenious means, has your fame arrived at my knowledge, receiving it from some of worth, who both in contemplation, and practise, owe to your honour their clearest service. I do not altogether look up at your title: the ancientest nobility, being but a relic of time past, and the truest honour indeed being for a man to confer honour on himself, which your learning strives to
propagate, and shall make you arrive at the dignity of a great example. I am confident this work is not unworthy your honour's perusal for by such poems as this, poets have kissed the hands of great princes, and drawn their gentle eyes to look down upon their sheets of paper, when the poets themselves were bound up in their winding-sheets. The like courtesy from your lordship, shall make you live in your grave, and laurel spring out of it when the ignorant scorners of the Muses (That like worms in libraries, seem to live only, to destroy learning) shall wither, neglected, and forgotten. This work and myself I humbly present to your approved censure. It being the utmost of my wishes, to have your honourable self my weighty and perspicuous comment: which grace so done me, shall ever be acknowledged

closer.signed: By your lordships in all duty and observance, John Webster.

div.head: In the just worth, of that well deserver, Mr. John Webster, and upon this masterpiece of tragedy.

lg.l: In this thou imitatest one rich, and wise,
That sees his good deeds done before he dies;
As he by works, thou by this work of fame,
Hast well provided for thy living name;
To trust to others honorings, is worth's crime,
Thy monument is raised in thy life time;
And 'tis most just; for every familiar man
Is his own marble; and his merit can
Cut him to any figure, and express
More art, than death's cathedral palaces,
Where royal ashes keep their court: thy note
Be ever plainness, 'tis the richest coat:
Thy epitaph only the title he,
Write, Duchess, that will fetch a tear for thee,
For whoe'er saw this Duchess live, and die,
That could get off under a bleeding eye.

lg.head: In tragaediam.
lg.l: Ut lux ex tenebris ictu percussa tonantis;
Illa, (Ruina malis) claris fit vita poetis.

closer.signed: Thomas middletonus, poëta and Chron: londinensis.

div.head: To his friend Mr. John Webster upon his Duchess of Malfi.
div.l: I never saw thy Duchess, till the day,
That she was lively bodied in thy play;
However she answered her low rated love,
Her brother's anger, did so far all prove,
Yet my opinion is, she might speak more;
But (Never in her life) so well before.

div.head: To the reader of the author, and his Duchess of Malfi.
div.l: Crown him a poet, whom nor Rome, nor Greece,
Transcend in all theirs, for a masterpiece:
In which, whiles words and matter change, and men,
Act one another; he, from whose clear pen.
They all took life, to memory hath lent
A lasting fame, to raise his monument.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Antonio, and Delio, Bosola, Cardinali.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.l: You are welcome to your country (Dear Antonio)
You have been long in France, and you return
A very formal Frenchman, in your habit.
How do you like the French court?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I admire it,
In seeking to reduce both state, and people
To a fixed order, there judicious King
Begins at home: quits first his royal palace
Of flattering sycophants of dissolute,
And infamous persons which he sweetly terms
His master's masterpiece (The work of heaven)
Considering duly, that a prince's court
Is like a common fountain, whence should flow,
Pure silver-drops in general: but if 't chance
Some cursed example poison't near the head,
"Death, and diseases through the whole land spread.
And what is't makes this blessed government,
But a most provident council, who dare freely
Inform him, the corruption of the times?
Though some oth' court hold it presumption ▪
To instruct princes what they ought to do,
It is a noble duty to inform them
What they ought to foresee: here comes Bosola
The only court-gall: yet I observe his railing
Is not for simple love of piety:
Indeed he rails at those things which he wants,
Would be as lecherous, covetous, or proud,
Bloody, or envious, as any man,
If he had means to be so: here's the Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I do haunt you still.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I have done you
Better service than to be slighted thus:
Miserable age, where only the reward
Of doing well, is the doing of it.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: You enforce your merit too-much.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I fell into the galleys in your service,
Where, for two years together, I wore two towels in stead of
A shirt, with a knot on the shoulder, after the fashion of a
Roman mantle: slighted thus? I will thrive some way:
Blackbirds fatten best in hard weather: why not I,
In these dog days?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Would you could become honest,

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: With all your divinity, do but direct me the way to it, I
Have known many travel far for it, and yet return as
Arrant knaves, as they went forth; because they carried
Themselves always a long with them; are you gone?
Some fellows (They say) are possessed with the devil,
But this great fellow, were able to possess the greatest
Devil, and make him worse.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He hath denied thee some suit?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: He, and his brother, are like plum-trees (That grow crooked
Over standing-pools) they are rich, and o'erladen with
Fruit, but none but crows, pies, and caterpillars feed
On them: could I be one of their flattering panders, I
Would hang on their ears like a horseleech, till I were full, an
then drop off: I pray leave me.
Who would rely upon these miserable dependences, in expectation to
Be advanced tomorrow? what creature, ever fed worse, then hoping
Tantalus? nor ever did any man more fearfully, than he that hoped
For a pleadon: there are rewards for hawks, and dogs, and
When they have done us service; but for a soldier, that hazards his
Limbs in a battle, nothing but a kind of geometry, is his last supportation.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Geometry?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Ay, to hang in a fair pair of slings, take his latter-swing in the
World, upon an honourable pair of crutches, from hospital
To hospital, fare ye well sir. And yet do not you scorn us, for
Places in the court, are but likes beds in the hospital, where this
Man's head lies at that man's foot, and so lower, and lower.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: I knew this fellow (Seven years) in the galleys,
For a notorious murder, and 'twas thought
The Cardinal suborned it: he was released
By the French general (Gaston de Foux)
When he recovered Naples.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis great pity
He should be thus neglected, I have heard
He's very valiant: this foul melancholy
Will poison all his goodness, for (I'll tell you)
If too immoderate sleep, be truly said
To be an inward rust unto the soul;
It then doth follow want of action
Breeds all black malcontents, and their close rearing
(Like moths in cloth) do hurt for want of wearing.

div.head: Scaena ii.
div.stage: Antonio, Delio, Ferdinand, Cardinal, Duchess, Castruchio, Silvio, Rodorico, Grisolan, Bosola, Julia, Cariola.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: The presence begins to fill, you promised me
To make me the partaker of the natures
Of some of your great courtiers.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The lord Cardinals
And other strangers, that are now in court,
I shall: here comes the great Calabrian Duke.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Who took the ring oftenest?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Antonia Bologna (My lord)

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Our sister Duchess great master of her household?
Give him the jewel: when shall we leave this sportive-action,
And fall to action indeed?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Methinks (My lord)
You should not desire to go to war, in person.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Now, for some gravity: why (My lord?)

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: It is fitting a soldier arise to be a prince, but not necessary
A prince descend to be a captain?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: No?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: No, (My lord)
He were far better do it by a deputy.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Why should he not as well sleep, or eat, by a deputy?
This might take idle, offensive, and base office from him,
Whereas the other deprives him of honour.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Believe my experience: that realm is never long in quiet,
Where the ruler, is a soldier.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Thou toldst me
Thy wife could not endure fighting.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: True (My lord.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And of a jest, she broke of a captain;
She met, full of wounds: I have forgotten it.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: She told him (My lord) he was a pitiful fellow, to lie,
Like the children of Ismael all in tents.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Why, there's a wit were able to undo
All the chirurgeons o'the city, for although
Gallants should quarrel, and had drawn their weapons,
And were ready to go to it; yet her persuasions would
Make them put up.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: That she would (My lord)
How do you like my Spanish jennet?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: He is all fire.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I am of Pliney's opinion, I think he was begotten by the wind,
he runs, as if he were ballassed with quicksilver.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: True (My lord) he reels from the tilt-often.

sp.speaker: Rod. Gris.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Why do you laugh? Methinks you that are courtiers
Should be my touchwood, take fire, when I give fire;
That is, laugh when I laugh, were the subject never so witty,

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: True (My lord) I myself have heard a very good jest,
And have scorned to seem to have so silly a wit, as to understand it.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: But I can laugh at your fool (My lord .)

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: He cannot speak (You know) but he makes faces,
My lady cannot abide him.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: No?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Nor endure to be in merry company: for she says
Too much laughing, and too much company, fills her
Too full of the wrinkle.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I would then have a mathematical instrument made for
Her face, that she might not laugh out of compass: I shall shortly
Visit you at Milan (Lord Silvio.)

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Your grace shall arrive most welcome.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: You are a good horseman (Antonio) you have excellent
Riders in France, what do you think of good horsemanship?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nobly (My lord) as out of the grecian-horse, issued
Many famous princes: so, out of brave horsemanship,
Arise the first sparks of growing resolution, that raise
The mind, to noble action.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: You have bespoke it worthily.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Your brother, the lord Cardinal, and sister Duchess.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Are the galleys come about?

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: They are (My lord.)

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Here's the lord Silvio, is come to take his leave.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Now (Sir) your promise: what's that Cardinal?
I mean his temper? they say he's a brave fellow,
Will play his five thousand crowns, at tennis, dance,
Court ladies, and one that hath fought single combats.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Some such flashes superficially hang on him, for form:
But observe his inward character: he is a melancholy
Churchman: the spring in his face, is nothing but the
engendering of toads: where he is jealous of any man.
He lays worse plots for them, then ever was imposed on
Hercules: for he strews in his way flatters, panders,
Intelligencers, atheists ,: and a thousand such political
Monsters: he should have been Pope: but in stead of
Coming to it, by the primitive decency of the church,
He did bestow bribes, so largely, and so impudently, as if he would
Have carried it away without heaven's knowledge. Some good he hath done.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: You have given too much of him: what's his brother?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The Duke there? A most perverse, and turbulent nature,
What appears in him mirth, is merely outside,
If he laugh heartily, it is to laugh
All honesty out of fashion.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Twins?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: In quality:
He speaks with others tongues, and hears men's suits,
With others ears: will seem to sleep o'th bench
Only to entrap offenders, in their answers;
Dooms men to death, by information,
Rewards, by hearsay.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Then the law to him
Is like a foul black cobweb, to a spider,
He makes it his dwelling, and a prison
To entangle those shall feed him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Most true:
He ne'er pays debts, unless they be showed turns,
And those he will confess, that he doth owe,
Last: for his brother, there, (The Cardinal)
They that do flatter him most, say oracles
Hang at his lips: and verily I believe them:
For the devil speaks in them.
But for their sister, (The right noble Duchess)
You never fixed you eye, on three fair medals,
Cast in one figure, of so different temper:
For her discourse, it is so full of rapture,
You only will begin, than to be sorry
when she doth end her speech: and wish (In wonder)
She held it less vainglory, to talk much
Then your penance, to hear her: whilst she speaks,
She throws upon a man, so sweet a look,
That it were able raise one to a galliard
That lay in a dead palsy; and to dote
On that sweet countenance: but in that look,
There speaketh so divine a continence,
As cuts off all lascivious, and vain hope.
Her days are practised in such noble virtue,
That, sure her nights (Nay more her very sleeps)
Are more in heaven, then other ladies' shrifts.
Let all sweet ladies, break their flattering glasses,
And dress themselves in her.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Fie Antonio,
You play the wiredrawer with her commendations.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll case the picture up: only thus much,
All her particular worth, grows to this sum:
She stains the time passed: lights the time to come,

sp.speaker: Cariola.
sp.l: You must attend my lady, in the gallery,
Some half an hour hence.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I shall.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Sister, I have a suit to you:

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: To me, sir?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: A gentleman here: Daniel de Bosola:
One, that was in the galleys.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Yes, I know him:

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: A worthy fellow he's: prey let me entreat for
The provisorship of your horse.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Your knowledge of him,
Commends him, and prefers him.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Call him hither,
We now upon parting: good lord Silvio
Do us commend to all our noble friends
At the leagues.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Sir, I shall.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: You are for Milan?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I am:

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Bring the caroches: we'll bring you down to the haven.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Be sure you entertain that Bosola
For your intelligence: I would not be seen in't.
And therefore many times I have slighted him,
When he did court our furtherance: as this morning.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Antonio, the great master of her household
Had been far fitter:

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: You are deceived in him,
His nature is too honest for such business,
He comes: I'll leave you:

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I was lured to you.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: My brother here (The Cardinal) could never abide you.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Never since he was in my debt.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: May be some oblique character in your face, made him suspect you?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Doth he study physiognomy?
There's no more credit, to be given to th'face,
Then to a sick man's urine, which some call
The physician's whore, because she cozens him:
He did suspect me wrongfully:

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: For that
You must give great men leave to take their times:
Distrust, doth cause us seldom be deceived;
You see, the oft shaking of the cedar-tree
Fastens it more at root.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Yet take heed:
For to suspect a friend unworthily,
Instructs him the next way to suspect you,
And prompts him to deceive you.

sp.speaker: Berd.
sp.l: There's gold.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: So:
What follows? (Never reigned such showers as these
Without thunderbolts i'th tail of them;) whose throat must I cut?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Your inclination to shed blood, rides post
Before my occasion to use you: I give you that
to live i'th court, here: and observe the Duchess,
To note all the particulars of her behaviour:
What suitors do solicit her for marriage
And whom she best affects: she's a young widow,
I would not have her marry again.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: No, sir?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Do not you ask the reason: but be satisfied,
I say I would not.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: It seems you would create me
One of your familiars.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Familiar? what's that?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Why, a very quaint invisible devil, in flesh:
An intelligencer.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Such a kind of thriving thing
I would wish thee: and ere long, thou mayst arrive
At a higher place by't.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Take your devils
Which hell calls angels: these cursed gifts would make
You a corrupter, me an impudent traitor,
And should I take these they 'll'd take me hell.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Sir, I'll take nothing from you, that I have given:
There is a place, that I procured for you
This morning: (The provisorship o'th' horse)
Have you heard on't?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Tis yours, is't not worth thanks?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I would have you curse yourself now, that your bounty
(Which makes men truly noble) ere should make
Me a villain: o, that to avoid ingratitude
For the good deed you have done me, I must do
All the ill man can invent: thus the devil
Candies all sins are: and what heaven terms vild,
That names he complemental.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Be yourself:
Keep your old garb of melancholy: 'twill express
You envy those that stand above your reach,
Yet strive not to come near 'em: this will gain
access, to private lodgings, where yourself
May (Like a politic dormouse,

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: As I have seen some,
Feed in a lord's dish, half asleep , not seeming
To listen to any talk: and yet these rogues
Have cut his throat in a dream: what's my place?
The provisors-ship o'th horse? say then my corruption
Grew out of horse-dung: I am your creature.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Let good men, for good deeds, covet good fame,
Since place, and riches oft are bribes of shame
Sometimes the devil doth preach. Exit Bosola.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: We are to part from you: and your own discretion
Must now be your director.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: You are a widow:
You know already what man is: and therefore
Let not youth: high promotion, eloquence,

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: No, nor any thing without the addition, honour,
Sway your high blood.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Marry? they are most luxurious,
Will wed twice.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: O fie:

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Their livers are more spotted
Than Laban's sheep.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Diamonds are of most value
They say; that have passed through most jewellers hands.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Whores, by that rule, are precious:

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Will you hear me?
I'll never marry:

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: So most widows say:
But commonly that motion lasts no longer
Than the turning of an hourglass, the funeral sermon,
And it, end both together.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Now hear me:
You live in a rank pasture here, i'th court,
There is a kind of honey-dew, that's deadly:
'Twill poison your fame; look to't: be not cunning:
for they whose faces do belie their hearts,
Are witches, ere they arrive at twenty years,
I: and give the devil suck.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: This is terrible good council:

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Hypocrisy is woven of a fine small thread,
(Subtler, than Vulcan's engine: yet (Believe't)
Your darkest actions: nay, your privat'st thoughts,
Will come to light.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: You may flatter yourself,
And take your own choice: privately be married
Under the eaves of night.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Think't the best voyage
That ere you made; like the irregular crab,
Which though't goes backward, thinks that it goes, right,
Because it goes its own way: but observe;
Such weddings, may more properly be said
To be executed, then celebrated.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: The marriage night
Is the entrance into some prison.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: And those joys,
Those lustful pleasures, are like heavy sleeps
Which do forerun man's mischief

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Fare you well.
Wisdom begins at the end: remember it.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I think this speech between you both was studied,
It came so roundly off.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: You are my sister,
This was my father's poniard: do you see,
I'd be loath to see't look rusty, 'cause 'twas his:
I would have you to give o'er these chargeable revels;
A vizor, and a masque are whispering rooms
That were ne'er built for goodness: fare ye well:
And women, like that part, which (Like the lamprey)
Hath ne'er a bone in't.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Fie sir:

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Nay,
I mean the tongue: variety of courtship;
what cannot a neat knave with a smooth tale,
Make a woman believe? farewell, lusty widow.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Shall this move me? if all my royal kindred
Lay in my way, unto this marriage:
I'd make them my low footsteps: and even now,
Even in this hate (As men in some great battles
By apprehending danger, have achieved
Almost impossible actions: I have heard soldiers say so,
So I, through frights, and threatenings, will assay
This dangerous venture: let old wife's report
I winked, and chose a husband: Cariola,
To thy known secrecy, I have given up
More than my life, my fame:

sp.speaker: Carolia.
sp.l: Both shall be safe:
For I'll conceal this secret from the world
As warily as those that trade in poison,
Keep poison from their children.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Thy protestation
Is ingenious, and hearty: I believe it.
Is Antonio come?

sp.speaker: Cariola.
sp.l: He attends you:

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Good dear soul,
Leave me: but place thyself behind the arras,
Where thou mayst overhear us: wish me good speed
For I am going into a wilderness,
Where I shall find nor path, nor friendly clue
To be my guide, I sent for you, sir down:
Take pen and ink, and write: are you ready?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes:

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: What did I say?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That I should write somewhat.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: O, I remember:
After this triumphs, and this large expense
It's fit (Like thrifty husbands) we inquire
What's laid up for tomorrow:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: So please your beauteous excellence.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Beauteous? Indeed I thank you: I look yong for your sake.
You have ta'en my cares upon you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll fetch your grace the
Particulars of your revenue, and expense.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: O, you are an upright treasurer: but you mistook,
For when I said I meant to make enquiry,
What's laid up for tomorrow: I did mean
What's laid up yonder for me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: In heaven,
I am making my will, (As 'tis fit princes should
In perfect memory) and I pray sir, tell me
Were not one better make it smiling, thus?
Then in deep groans, and terrible ghastly looks,
As if the gifts we parted with, procured
That violent destruction?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O, much better.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: If I had a husband now, this care were quit:
But I intend to make yond overseer;
What good deed, shall we first remember? say.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Begin with that first good deed, began i'th' world,
After man's creation, the sacrament of marriage,
I'd have you first provide for a good husband,
Give him all.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: All?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, your excellent self.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: In a winding sheet?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: In a couple.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: St. Winfrid, that were a strange will.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Twere strange if there were no will in you
To marry again.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: What do you think of marriage?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I take't, as those that deny purgatory,
It locally contains, or heaven, or hell,
There's no third place in't.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: How do you affect it?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My banishment, feeding my melancholy,
Would often reason thus.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Pray let's hear it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Say a man never marry, nor have children,
What takes that from him? only the bare name
Of being a father, or the weak delight
To see the little wanton, ride a cockhorse
Upon a painted stick, or hear him chatter
Like a taught starling.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Fie, fie, what's all this?
One of your eyes is bloodshot, use my ring to't,
They say 'tis very sovereign, 'twas my wedding ring,
And I did vow never to part with it,
But to my second husband.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You have parted with it now.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Yes, to help your eyesight.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You have made me stark blind.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: There is a saucy, and ambitious devil
Is dancing in this circle.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Remove him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: There needs small conjuration, when your finger
May do it: thus, is it fit?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What said you?He kneels

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Sir,
This goodly roof of yours, it too low built,
I cannot stand upright in't, nor discourse,
Without I raise it higher: raise yourself,
Or if you please, my hand to help you: so.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ambition (Madam) is a great man's madness,
That is not kept in chains, and close-pent-roomes,
But in fair lightsome lodgings, and is girt
With the wild noise of prattling visitans,
Which makes it lunatic, beyond all cure,
Conceive not, I am so stupid, but I aim
Whereto your favours tend: but he's a fool
That (Being a cold) would thrust his hands i'th' fire
To warm them.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: So, now the ground's broke,
You may discover what a wealthy mine,
I make you lord off.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O my unworthiness.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: You were ill to sell yourself,
This darkening of your worth, is not like that
Which tradesmen use i'th' city, their false lights
Are to rid bad wares off: and I must tell you
If you will know where breathes a complete man,
(I speak it without flattery) turn your eyes,
And progress through yourself.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Were there nor heaven, nor hell,
I should be honest: I have long served virtue,
And ne'er ta'en wages of her.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Now she pays it,
The misery of us, that are born great,
We are forced to woo, because none dare woo us:
And as a tyrant doubles with his words,
And fearfully equivocates: so we
Are forced to express our violent passions
In riddles, and in dreams, and leave the path
Of simple virtue, which was never made
To seem the thing it is not: go, go brag
You have left me heartless, mine is in your bosom,
I hope 'twill multiply love there: you do tremble:
Make not your heart so dead a piece of flesh
To fear, more than to love me: sir, be confident,
What is't distracts you? This is flesh, and blood, (Sir,)
'Tis not the figure cut in alablaster
Kneels at my husband's tomb: awake, awake (Man)
I do here put of all vain ceremony,
And only do appear to you, a young widow
That claims you for her husband, and like a widow,
I use but half a blush in't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Truth speak for me,
I will remain the constant sanctuary
Of your good name.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I thank you (Gentle love)
And 'cause you shall not come to me, in debt,
(Being now my steward) here upon your lips
I sign your quietus est: this you should have begged now,
I have seen children oft eat sweetmeats thus,
As fearful to devour them too soon.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But for your brothers?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Do not think of them,
All discord, without this circumference,
Is only to be pitied, and not feared:
Yet, should they know it, time will easily
Scatter the tempest.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: These words should be mine,
And all the parts you have spoke, if some part of it
Would not have savoured flattery.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Kneel.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Be not amazed, this woman's of my council,
I have heard lawyers say, a contract in a chamber,
(Per verba presenti) is absolute marriage:
Bless (Heaven) this sacred Gordian, which, let violence
Never untwine.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And may our sweet affections, (Like the spheres)
Be still in motion.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Quickening, and make
The like soft music.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That we may imitate the loving palms
(Best emblem of a peaceful marriage)
That ne'er bore fruit divided.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: What can the church force more?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That fortune may not know an accident
Either of joy, or sorrow, to divide
Our fixed wishes.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: How can the church build faster?
We now are man, and wife, and 'tis the church
That must but echo this: maid, stand a part,
I now am blind.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What's your conceit in this?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I would have you lead your fortune by the hand.
Unto your marriage bed:
(You speak in me this, for we now are one)
We'll only lie, and talk together, and plot
T'appease my humorous kindred; and if you please
(Like the old tale, in Alexander and Lodowick)
Lay a naked sword between us, keep us chaste:
O, let me shroud my blushes in your bosom,
Since 'tis the treasury of all my secrets.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Whether the spirit of greatness, or of woman
Reign most in her, I know not, but it shows
A fearful madness, I owe her much of pity. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena i.
div.stage: Bosola, Castruchio, an old lady, Antonio, Delio, Duchess, rodorico, Grisolan.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: You say you would fain be taken, for an eminent courtier?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: 'Tis the very main of my ambition.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Let me see, you have a reasonable good face for't already,
And your nightcap expresses your ears sufficient largely,
I would have you learn to twirl the strings of your band with a
Good grace; and in a set speech, (At th'end of every sentence,)
To hum, three, or four times, or blow your nose (Till it smart again,)
To recover your memory, when you come to be a precedent in
Criminal causes, if you smile upon a prisoner, hang him, but if
You frown upon him, and threaten him, let him be sure to scape
The gallows.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I would be a very merry precedent,

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Do not sup a nights, 'twill beget you an admirable wit.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Rather it would make me have a good stomach to quarrel,
For they say, you roaring-bois eat meat seldom,
And that makes them so valiant:
But how shall I know whether the people take me
for an eminent fellow.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I will teach a trick to know it,
Give out you lie a dying, and if you
Hear the common people curse you,
Be sure you are taken for one of the prime nightcaps,
You come from painting now?

sp.speaker: Old lady.
sp.l: From what?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Why, from your scurvy face-physic,
To behold thee not painted inclines somewhat near
A miracle: these in thy face here, were deep ruts,
And foul sloughs the last progress:
There was a lady in France, that having had the small pocks,
Flayed the skin off her face, to make it more level;
And whereas before she looked like a nutmeg-grater,
After she resembled an abortive hedgehog.

sp.speaker: Old lady.
sp.l: Do you call this painting?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: No, no but you call carreening of an old
Morphewed lady, to make her disembogue again,
There's roughcast phrase to your plastic.

sp.speaker: Old lady.
sp.l: It seems you are well acquainted with my closet?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: One would suspect it for a shop of witchcraft,
To find in it the fat of serpents; spawn of snakes, Jews spittle,
And their young children ordures, and all these for the face:
I would sooner eat a dead pigeon ▪ taken from the soles of the feet
Of one sick of the plague, then kiss one of you fasting:
Here are two of you, whose sin of your youth, is the very
Patrimony of the physician, makes him renew his
Foot-cloth with the spring, and change his
High-prized courtesan with the fall of the leaf:
I do wonder you do not loathe yourselves,
Observe my meditation now:
What thing is in this outward form of man
To be beloved? we account it ominous,
If nature do produce a colt, or lamb,
A fawn, or goat, in any limb resembling
A man; and fly from't as a prodigy.
Man stands amazed to see his deformity,
in any other creature but himself.
But in our own flesh, though we bear diseases
Which have their true names, only ta'en from beasts,
As the most ulcerous wolf, and swinish measel;
Though we are eaten up of lice, and worms,
And though continually we bear about us
A rotten and dead body, we delight
To hide it in rich tissue all our fear,
(Nay all our terror) is, lest our physician
Should put us in the ground, to be made sweet.
Your wife's gone to Rome: you two couple, and get you
To the wells at Leuca, to recover your aches.
I have other work on foot: I observe our Duchess
Is sick a days, she pukes, her stomach seethes,
The fins of her eyelids, look most teeming blue,
She wanes i'th' cheek, and waxes fat i'th' flank;
And (Contrary to our Italian fashion,)
Wears a loose-bodied gown, there's somewhat in't,
I have a trick, may chance discover it
(A pretty one) I have bought some apicocks,
The first our spring yields.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: And so long since married?
You amaze me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let me seal your lips for ever,
For did I think, that any thing but th'air,
Could carry these words from you, I should wish
You had no breath at all: now sir, in your contemplation?
You are studying to become a great wise fellow?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: O sir, the opinion of wisdom, is a foul tetter,
That runs all over a man's body: if simplicity
Direct us to have no evil, it directs us to a happy
Being: for the subtlest folly proceeds from the
Subtlest wisdom: let me be simply honest.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I do understand your inside.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Do you so?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Because you would not seem to appear to th'world
Puffed up with your preferment: you continue
this out off fashion melancholy, leave it, leave it.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Give me leave to be honest in any phrase, in any
Compliment whatsoever, shall I confess myself to you?
I look no higher than I can reach:
They are the gods, that must ride on winged horses,
A lawyer's mule of a slow pace, will both surt
My disposition, and business: for (Mark me)
When a man's mind rides faster than his horse can gallop,
They quickly both tire.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You would look up to heaven, but I think
The devil, that rules i'th' air, stands in your light.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: O (Sir) you are lord of the ascendant,
Chief man with the Duchess, a Duke was your
Cousin german, removed: say you were lineally
Descended from King pippin, or he himself,
What of this? search the heads of the greatest rivers in
The world, you shall find them but bubbles of water:
Some would think the souls of princes were brought
Forth by some more weighty cause, than those of meaner persons,
They are deceived, there's the same hand to them:
The like passions sway them, the same reason, that makes
A vicar go to law for a tithe-pig,
And undo his neighbours, makes them spoil
A whole province, and batter down goodly
Cities, with the cannon.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Your arm Antonio, do I not grow fat?
I am exceeding short-winded: Bosola,
I would have you (Sir) provide for me a litter,
Such a one, as the Duchess of Florence road in.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: The Duchess used one, when she was great with child .

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I think she did: come hither, mend my ruff,
Here, when? thou art such a tedious lady; and
Thy breath smells of lemon pills, would thou hadst done,
Shall I sound under thy fingers? I am
So troubled with the mother.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I fear to much.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I have heard you say, that the French couriers
wear their hats on fore the King.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have seen it.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: In the presence?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes:
Why should not we bring up that fashion?
'Tis ceremony more than duty, that consists
In the removing of a piece of felt:
Be you the example to the rest o'th' court,
Put on your hat first.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You must pardon me:
I have seen, in colder countries, then in France,
Nobles stand bare to th'prince; and the distinction
My thought showed reverently.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I have a present for your grace.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: For me sir?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Apricots (Madam.)

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: O sir, where are they?
I have heard of none to year.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Good, her colour rises.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Indeed I thank you: they are wondrous fair ones:
What an unskilful fellow is our gardener?
We shall have none this month.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Will not your grace pare them?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: No, they taste of musk ( methinks ) indeed they do:

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I know not: yet I wish your grace had pared 'em:

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I forgotten to tell you the knave gardner,
(Only to raise his profit by them the sooner)
Did ripen them in horse-dung.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: O you jest:
You shall judge: pray taste one.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Indeed madam,
I do not love the fruit.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Sir, you are loath
To rob us of our dainties: 'tis a delicate fruit,
They say they are restorative?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: 'Tis a pretty
art: this grafting.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: 'Tis so: a bettering of nature.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: To make a pippin grow upon a crab,
A damson on a black thorn: how greedily she eats them!
A whirlwind strike off these bawd-farthingalls,
For, but for that, and the loose-bodied gown,
I should have discovered apparently
The young spring-hall cutting a caper in her belly.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I thank you (Bosola:) they were right good ones,
If they do not make me sick.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How now madam?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: This green fruit: and may stomach are not friends
How they swell me!

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Nay, you are too much swelled already.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: O, I am in an extreme cold sweat.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I am very sorry:

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Lights to my chamber: oh, good Antonio,
I fear I am undone. Exit Duchess.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Lights there, lights.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O my most trusty Delio, we are lost:
I fear she's fallen in labour: and there's left
No time for her remove.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Have you prepared
Those ladies to attend her? and procured
That politic safe conveyance for the midwife
Your Duchess plotted.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have:

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Make use then of this forced occasion:
Give out that Bosola hath poisoned her,
With these apricots: that will give some colour ▪
For her keeping close.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Fie, fie, the physicians
Will then flock to her.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: For that you may pretend
She'll use some prepared antidote of her own,
Lest the physicians should repoison her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am lost in amazement: I know not what to think on't. Ex.

div.head: Scaena. Ii.
div.stage: Bosola, old lady, Antonio, Rodorigo, Grisolan: servants, Delio, Cariola.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: So, so: there's no question but her tetchiness
And most vulturous eating of the apricots, are apparent
Signs of breeding, now?

sp.speaker: Old lady.
sp.l: I am in haste (Sir.)

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: There was a young waiting-woman, had a monstrous desire
To see the glass-house.

sp.speaker: Old la.
sp.l: Nay, pray let me go:

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: And it was only to know what strange instrument it was,
Should swell up a glass to the fashion of a woman's belly.

sp.speaker: Old la.
sp.l: I will hear no more of the glass-house,
You are still abusing women?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Who I? no, only (By the way now and then) mention
Your frailties. The orange tree bear ripe and green
Fruit and blossoms altogether: and some of you give entertainment
For pure love: but more, for more precious reward. The lusty
Spring smells well: but drooping autumn tastes well: if we
Have the same golden showers, that rained in the time of Jupiter
The thunderer: you have the same Danes still, to hold up their
Laps to receive them: didst thou never study the mathematics?

sp.speaker: Old la.
sp.l: What's that (Sir.)

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Why, to know the trick how to make a many lines meet
In one centre: go go; give your foster-daughters good counsel
Tell them, that the devil takes delight to hang a woman's girdle;
Like a false rusty watch that she cannot discern how
The time passes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Shut up the court gates:

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Why sir? what's the danger?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Shut up the posterns presently: and call
All the officers o'th' court.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: I shall instantly:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Who keeps the key o'th' park-gate?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Forobosco.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let him bring't presently.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: O, gentlemen, o'th' court, the foulest treason.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: If that these apricots should be poisoned, now;
Without my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: There was taken even now a Swisser
In the Duchess bedchamber.

sp.speaker: 2. Servant
sp.l: A Swisser?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: With a pistol in his great codpiece.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: The codpiece was the case for't.

sp.speaker: 2. Servant
sp.l: There was a cunning traitor.
Who would have searched his codpiece?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: True, if he had kept out of the ladies' chambers:
And all the molds of his buttons, were leaden bullets.

sp.speaker: 2. Servant
sp.l: O wicked cannibal: a firelock in's codpiece?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: 'Twas a French plot upon my life.

sp.speaker: 2. Servant
sp.l: To see what the devil can do.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: All the offices here?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: We are:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Gentlemen,
We have lost much plate you know; and but this evening
Jewels, to the value of four thousand ducats
Are missing in the Duchess' cabinet,
Are the gates shut?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis the Duchess pleasure
Each officer be locked into his chamber
Till the sunrising: and to send the keys
Of all their chests, and of their outward doors
Into her bedchamber: she is very sick.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: At her pleasure.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She entreats you take't not ill: the innocent
Shall be the more approved by it.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Gentleman o'th' woodyard, where's your Swisser now?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: By this hand 'twas credibly reported by one o'th' blackguard.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: How fares it with the Duchess?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She's exposed
unto the worst of torture, pain, and fear;

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Speak to her all happy comfort.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How I do play the fool with mine own danger?
You are this night (Dear friend) to post to Rome,
My life lies in your service.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Do not doubt me,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O, 'tis far from me: and yet fear presents me
Somewhat that look like danger.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Believe it,
'Tis but the shadow of your fear, no more:
How superstitiously we mind our evils?
The throwing down salt, or crossing of a hare;
Bleeding at nose, the stumbling of a horse:
Or singing of a cricket, are of power
To daunt whole man in us: sir, fare you well:
I wish you all the joys of a blessed father;
And (For my faith) lay this unto your breast,
Old friends (Like old swords) still are trusted best.

sp.speaker: Cariola.
sp.l: Sir, you are the happy father of a son,
Your wife commends him to you.

sp.speaker: A●t.
sp.l: Blessed comfort:
For heaven-sake tend her well: I'll presently
Go set a figure for's nativity. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena. Iii.
div.stage: Bosola, Antonio.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Sure I did hear a woman shriek: list, hah?
And the sound came (If I received it right)
From the Duchess lodgings: there's some stratagem,
In the confining all our courtiers
To their several wards: I must have part of it,
My intelligence will freeze else: list again,
It may be 'twas the melancholy bird,
(Best friend of silence, and of solitariness)
The owl, that screamed so: hah? Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I heard some noise: who's there? what art thou? speak.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Antonio? Put not your face; nor body
To such a forced expression of fear,
I am Bosola; your friend.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Bosola?
(This mole does undermine me) heard you not
A noise even now?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: From whence?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: From the Duchess lodging.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Not I: did you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I did: or else I dreamed.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Let's walk towards it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No: it may be, 'twas
But the rising of the wind:

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Very likely:
Methinks 'tis very cold, and yet you sweat.
You look wildly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have been setting a figure
For the Duchess jewels;

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Ah: and how falls your question?
Do you find it radical?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What's that to you?
'Tis rather to be questioned what design
(When all men were commanded to their lodgings)
Makes you a nightwalker.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: In sooth I'll tell you:
Now all the court's asleep, I thought the devil
Had least to do here; I came to say my prayers,
And if it do offend you, I do so,
You are a fine courtier.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This fellow will undo me;
You gave the Duchess apricots today,
Pray heaven they were not poisoned?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Poisoned? A Spanish fig
For the imputation.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Traitors are ever confident,
Till they are discovered: there were jewels stolen too,
in my conceit, none are to be suspected
More than yourself.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: You are a false steward.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Saucy slave: I'll pull thee up by the roots;

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: May be the ruin will crush you to pieces.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You are an impudent snake indeed (Sir)
Are you scarce warm, and do you show your sting?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You libel well (Sir.)

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: No (Sir,)
Copy it out: and I will set my hand to't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My nose bleeds: one that were superstitious, would count
This ominous: when it merely comes by chance.
Two letters, that are wrought here, for my name
Are drowned in blood: mere accident: for you (Sir) I'll take order:
I'th morn you shall be safe: 'tis that must colour
Her lying-in: sir, this door you pass not:
I do not hold it fit, that you come near
The Duchess lodgings, till you have quite yourself;
The great are like the base; nay, they are the same.
When they seek shameful ways, to avoid shame. Ex.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Antonio here about, did drop a paper,
Some of your help (False-friend) o, here it is:
What's here? A child's nativity calculated?
sp.p: The Duchess was delivered of a son, between the hours twelve, and one, in the night ▪ anno dom: 1504. (That's this year) decimo nono decembris, (That's this night) taken according to the meridian of Malfi (That's our Duchess: happy discovery) the lord of the first house, being combust in the ascendant, signifies short life: and Mars being in a human sign, joined to the tail of the dragon, in the eight house, doth threaten a violent death; caeteta non scrutantur.
sp.l: Why now 'tis most apparent: this precise fellow
Is the Duchess bawd: I have it to my wish:
This is a parcel of intelligency
Our courtiers were cased-up for? It needs must follow,
That I must be committed, on pretence
Of poisoning her: which I'll endure, and laugh at:
if one could find the father now: but that
Time will discover; old Castruchio
I'th morning posts to Rome; by him I'll send
A letter, that shall make her brother's galls
O'erflow their livers, this was a thrifty way.
Though lust do mask in ne'er so strange disguise,
She's oft found witty, but is never wise.

div.head: Scaena. Iiii.
div.stage: Cardinal, and Julia, servant, and Delio.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Sit: thou art my best of wishes, prithee tell me
What trick didst thou invent to come to Rome,
Without thy husband.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why, (My lord) I told him
I came to visit an old anchorite
Hear, for devotion

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Thou art a witty false one:
I mean to him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You have prevailed with me
Beyond my strongest thoughts: I would not now
Find you inconstant.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Do not put thyself
To such a voluntary torture: which proceeds
Out of your own guilt.

sp.speaker: Iul,
sp.l: How (My lord?)

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: You fear my constancy, because you have approved
Those giddy and wild turning in yourself.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Did you ere find them?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Sooth generally for women;
A man might strive to make glass malleable,
Ere he should make them fixed.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: So, (My lord)

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: We had need go borrow that fantastic glass
Invented by Galileo the florentine,
To view another spacious world i'th' moon,
and look to find a constant woman there.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: This is very well (My lord.)

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Why do you weep?
Are tears your justification? the selfsame tears
Will fall into your husband's bosom, (Lady)
With a loud protestation, that you love him
Above the world: come, I'll love you wisely,
That's jealously, since I am very certain
You cannot me make cuckold.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I'll go home
To my husband.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: You may thank me, (Lady)
I have taken you off your melancholy perch,
Boar you upon my fist, and showed you 'Game,
And let you fly at it: I pray thee kiss me,
When thou was't with thy husband, thou was't watched
Like a tame elephant: (Still you are to thank me)
Thou hadst only kisses from him, and high feeding,
But what delight was that? 'twas just like one
That hath a little lingering on the lute,
Yet cannot tune it: (Still you are to thank me.)

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You told me of a piteous wound i'th' heart,
And a sick liver, when you wooed me first,
And spoke like one in physic.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Who's that?
Rest firm, for my affection to thee,
Lightning moves slow to't.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: (Madam) a gentleman
That's come post from Malfi, desires to see you.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Let him enter, I'll withdraw. Exit.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: He says,
Your husband , (Old Castruchio) is come to Rome,
Most pitifully tired with riding post.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Signior Delio? 'tis one of my old suitors

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: I was bold to come and see you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Sir, you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Do you lie here?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Sure, your own experience
Will satisfy you no, our Roman prelates
Do not keep lodging, for ladies.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Very well:
I have brought you no commendations from your husband ,
For I know none by him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I hear he's come to Rome?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: I never knew man, and beast, of a horse, and a knight,
So weary of each other, if he had had a good back,
He would have undertaken to have born his horse,
His breech was so pitifully sore.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Your laughter,
Is my pity.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Lady, I know not whether
You want money, but I have brought you some.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: From my husband?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: No, from mine own allowance.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I must hear the condition, ere I be bound to take it.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Look on't, 'tis gold, hath it not a fine colour?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I have a bird more beautiful.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Try the sound on't.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: A lutestring far exceeds it,
It hath no smell, like cassia, or civet,
Nor is it physical, though some fond doctors
Persuade us, seethes in cullises, I'll tell you,
This is a creature bred by —

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Your husband's come,
Hath delivered a letter to the Duke of Calabria, that,
To my thinking hath put him out of his wits.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Sir, you hear,
Pray let me know your business, and your suit,
As briefly as can be.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: With good speed, I would wish you
(At such time, as you are nonresident
With your husband) my mistress.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Sir, I'll go ask my husband if I shall,
And straight return your answer. Exit.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Very fine,
is this her wit, or honesty that speaks thus?
I heard one say the Duke was highly moved
With a letter sent from Malfi: I do fear
Antonio is betrayed: how fearfully
Shows his ambition now, (Unfortunate fortune)
"They pass through whirlpools, and deep woes do shun,
Who the event weigh, ere the action's done. Exit.

div.head: Scaena v.
div.stage: Cardinal, and Ferdinand, with a letter.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I have this night digged up a mandrake.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Say you?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: And I am grown mad with't.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: What's the prodigy?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Read there, a sister dampened, she's loose i'th' hilt:
Grown a notorious strumpet.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Speak lower.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Lower?
Rogue's do not whisper't now, but seek to publish't,
(As servants do the bounty of their lords)
Aloud; and with a covetous searching eye,
To mark who note them: o confusion seize her,
She hath had most cunning bawds to serve her turn,
And more secure conveyances for lust,
Than towns of garrison, for service.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Is't possible?
Can this be certain?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Rhubarb, o, for rhubarb
To purge this choler, here's the cursed day
To prompt my memory, and here'it shall stick
Till of her bleeding heart, I make a sponge
To wipe it out.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Why do you make yourself
So wild a tempest?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Would I could be one,
That I might toss her palace about her ears,
Root up her goodly forests, blast her meads,
And lay her general territory as waste,
As she hath done her honours.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Shall our blood?
(The royal blood of Arragon, and Castille)
Be thus attainted?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Apply desperate physic,
We must not now use balsamum, but fire,
The smarting cupping-glass, for that's the mean
To purge infected blood, (Such blood as hers:)
There is a kind of pity in mine eye,
I'll give it to my handkercher; and now 'tis here,
I'll bequeath this to her bastard.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: What to do?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Why, to make soft lint for his mother wounds,
When I have hewed her to pieces.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Cursed creature,
Unequal nature, to place women's hearts
So far upon the left-side.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Foolish men,
That ere will trust their honour in a bark,
Made of so slight, weak-bulrush, as is woman,
Apt every minute to sink it?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Thus
Ignorance, when it hath purchased honour,
It cannot wield it.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Methinks I see her laughing,
Excellent hyena, talk to me somewhat, quickly,
Or my imagination will carry me
To see her, in the shameful act of sin.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: With whom?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Happily, with some strong thighed bargeman;
Or one th'wood-yard, that can quoit the sledge,
Or toss the bar, or else some lovely squire
That carries coals up, to her privy lodgings.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: You fly beyond your reason.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Go to (Mistress.)
'Tis not your whore's milk, that shall quench my wildfire,
But your whore a blood.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: How idly shows this rage?
Which carries you, as men conveyed by witches, through the air,
On violent whirlwinds, this intemperate noise,
Fitly resembles deaf-men's shrill discourse,
Who talk aloud, thinking all other men
To have their imperfection.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Have not you,
My palsy?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Yes, I can be angry
Without this rupture, there is not in nature
A thing, that makes man so deformed, so beastly,
As doth intemperate anger: chide yourself,
You have divers men, who never yet expressed
Their strong desire of rest, but by unrest,
By vexing of themselves: come, put yourself
In tune.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: So, I will only study to seem
The thing I am not: I could kill her now,
In you, or in myself, for I do think
It is some sin in us, heaven doth revenge
By her.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Are you stark mad?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I would have their bodies
Burnt in a coalpit, with the ventage stopped,
That their cursed smoke might not ascend to heaven:
Or dip the sheets they lie in, in pitch or sulphur,
Wrap them in't, and then light them like a match:
Or else to boil their bastard to a cullis,
And give't his lecherous father, to renew
The sin of his back.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Nay, I have done,
I am confident, had I been damned in hell,
and should have heard of this, it would have put me
Into a cold sweat: in, in, I'll go sleep,
Till I know who leaps my sister, I'll not stir:
That known, I'll find scorpions to string my whips,
And fix her in a general eclipse. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena i.
div.stage: Antonio, and Delio, Duchess, Ferdinand, Bosola.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Our noble friend (My most beloved Delio)
O, you have been a stranger long at court,
Came you along with the lord Ferdinand?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: I did sir, and how fairs your noble Duchess?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Right fortunately well: she's an excellent
Feeder of pedigrees: since you last saw her,
She hath had two children more, a son, and daughter.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Methinks 'twas yesterday: let me but wink,
And not behold your face, which to mine eye
Is somewhat leaner, verily I should dream
It were within this half hour.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You have not been in law, (Friend Delio)
Nor in prison, nor a suitor at the court
Nor begged the reversion of some great man's place,
Nor troubled with an old wife, which doth make
Your time so insensibly hasten.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Pray sir tell me,
Hath not this news arrived yet to the ear;
Of the lord Cardinal?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I fear it hath,
The lord Ferdinand, (That's newly come to court,)
Doth bear himself right dangerously.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Pray why?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He is so quiet, that he seems to sleep
The tempest out (As dormice do in winter,)
Those houses, that are haunted, are most still,
till the devil be up.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: What say the common people.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The common-rabble, do directly say
She is a strumpet.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: And your graver heads,
(Which would he politic) what censure they?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: They do observe, I grow to infinite purchase
The left-hand way, and all suppose the Duchess
Would amend it, if she could: for, say they
Great princes, though they grudge their officers
Should have such large, and unconfined means
To get wealth under them, will not complain
Lest thereby they should make them odious
Unto the people, for other obligation
Of love, or marriage, between her and me,
They never dream of.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: The lord Ferdinand
Is going to bed.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I'll instantly to bed,
For I am weary: I am to be bespeak
A husband for you.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: For me (Sir?) pray who is't?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: The great count Malateste.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Fie upon him,
A count? he's a mere stick of sugar-candy,
(You may look quite through him) when I choose
A husband, I will marry for your honour.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: You shall do well in't: how is't (Worthy Antonio?)

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: But (Sir) I am to have private conference with you,
About a scandalous report, is spread
Touching mine honour.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Let me be ever deaf to't:
One of Pasquil's paper-bullets, court calumny,
A pestilent air, which princes palaces
Are seldom purged off: yet, say that it were true,
I pour it in your bosom, my fixed love,
Would strongly excuse, extenuate, nay deny
faults where they apparent in you: go be safe
In your own innocency.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: O blessed comfort,
This deadly air is purged. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Her guilt treads on
Hot burning cultures: now Bosola,
How thrives our intelligence?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: (Sir) uncertainly,
'Tis rumoured she hath had three bastards, but
By whom, we may go read i'th' stars.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Why some
Hold opinion, all things are written there.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Yes, if we could find spectacles to read them,
I do suspect, there hath been some sorcery
Used on the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Sorcery, to what purpose?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: To make her dote on some desertless fellow,
She shames to acknowledge.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Can your faith, give way
To think there's power in potions, or in charms,
To make us love, whether we will or no?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Most certainly.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: A way, these are mere gullcries, horrid things
Invented by some cheating mountebanks
To abuse us: do you think that herbs, or charms
Can force the will? Some trials have been made
In this foolish practice; but the ingredients
Were lenitive poisons, such as are of force
To make the patient mad; and straight the witch
Swears (By equivocation, they are in love.
The witchcraft lies in her rank bood: this night
I will force confession from her: you told me
You had got (Within these two days) a false key
Into her bedchamber.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I have.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: As I would wish.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: What do you intend to do?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Can you guess?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: No:

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Do not ask then:
He that can compass me, and know my drifts,
May say he hath put a girdle about the world,
And sounded all her quicksands.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I do not
Think so.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: What do you think then? pray?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: That you are
Your own chronicle too much: and grossly
Flatter yourself.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Give me thy hand, I thank thee:
I never gave pension but to flatterers,
Till I entertained thee: farewell,
That friend a great man's ruin strongly checks,
Who rails into his belief, all his defects. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena. Ii.
div.stage: Duchess, Antonio, Cariola, Ferdinand, Bosola, officers.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Bring me the casket hither, and the glass;
You get no lodging here, tonight (My lord.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Indeed, I must persuade one:

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Very good:
I hope in time 'twill grow into a custom,
That noble men shall come with cap, and knee,
To purchase a night's lodging, of their wives.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I must lie here.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Must? you are a lord of misrule.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Indeed, my rule is only in the night.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: To what use will you put me,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: We'll sleep together:

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Alas, what pleasure can two lovers find in sleep?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: My lord, I lie with her often: and I know
she'll much disquiet you:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: See, you are complained of.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: For she's the sprawlingst bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I shall like her the better for that.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Sir, shall I ask you a question?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I pray thee Cariola.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Wherefore still when you lie with my lady
Do you rise so early?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Labouring men,
Count the clock oftenest Cariola,
Are glad when their task's ended.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I'll stop your mouth.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay, that's but one, Venus had two soft doves
To draw her chariot: I must have another:
When wilt thou marry, Cariola?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Never (My lord.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O fie upon this single life: forgo it:
We read how Daphne, for her peevish slight
Became a fruitless bay-tree: Sirinx turned
To the pale empty reed: Anaxarate
Was frozen into marble: whereas those
Which married, or proved kind unto their friends
Were, by a gracious influence, transhaped
Into the olive, pomegranate, mulberry:
Became flowers, precious stones, or eminent stars.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: This is a vain poetry: but I pray you tell me,
If there were proposed me, wisdom, riches, and beauty,
In three several young men, which should I choose?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis a hard question: this was Paris case
And he was blind in't, and there was great cause:
For how was't possible he could judge right,
Having three amorous goddesses in view,
And they stark naked: 'twas a motion
Were able to benight the apprehension
Of the severest counsellor of Europe.
Now I look on both your faces, so well formed
It puts me in mind of a question, I would ask.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I do wonder why hard-favoured ladies
For the most part, keep worse-favoured waiting women,
To attend them, and cannot endure fair-ones.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: O, that's soon answered.
Did you ever in your life know an ill painter
Desire to have his dwelling next door to the shop
Of an excellent picture-maker? 'twould disgrace
His face-making, and undo him: I prithee
When were we so merry? my hair tangles.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Prithee (Cariola) let's steal forth the room,
And let her talk to herself: I have divers times
Served her the like, when she hath chafed extremely:
I love to see her angry: softly Cariola. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Doth not the colour of my hair 'gin to change?
When I wax grey, I shall have all the court
Powder their hair, with arras, to be like me:
You have cause to love me, I entered you into my heart
Before you would vouchsafe to call for the keys.
We shall one day have my brothers take you napping:
Methinks his presence (Being now in court)
Should make you keep your own bed: but you'll say
Love mixed with fear, is sweetest: I'll assure you
You shall get no more children till my brother's
Consent to be your gossips: have you lost your tongue? 'tis welcome:
For know whether I am doomed to live, or die,
I can do both like a prince. Ferdinand gives her a poniard.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Die then, quickly:
Virtue, where art thou hid? what hideous thing
Is it, that doth eclipse thee?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Pray sir hear me:

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Or is it true, thou art but a bare name,
And no essential thing?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Sir:

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Do not speak.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: No sir:
I will plant my soul in mine cares, to hear you.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: O most imperfect light of human reason,
That mak'st so unhappy, to fore see
What we can least prevent: pursue thy wishes:
And glory in them: there's in shame no comfort,
But to be passed all bounds, and sense of shame.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I pray sir, hear me: I am married,

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: So:

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Happily, not to your liking: but for that
Alas: your shears do come untimely now
To clip the birds wings, that's already flown:
Will you see my husband?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Yes, if I
Could change eyes with a basilisque:

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Sure, you came hither
By his confederacy.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: The howling of a wolf
Is music to the (Screech-owl) prithee peace:
Whate'er thou art, that hast enjoyed my sister,
(For I am sure thou hearst me) for thine own sake
Let me not know thee: I came hither, prepared
To work thy discovery: yet am now persuaded
It would beget such violent effects
As would damp us both: I would not for ten millions
I had beheld thee: therefore use all means
I never may have knowledge of thy name;
Enjoy thy lust still, and a wretched life,
On that condition: and for thee (Vild woman,)
If thou do wish thy lecher may grow old
In thy embracements, I would have thee build
Such a room for him, as our anchorites
To holier use inhabit: let not the sun
Shine on him, till he's dead: let dogs, and monkeys
Only converse with him, and such dumb things
To whom nature denies use, to sound his name.
Do not keep a paraquito, lest she learn it;
If thou do love him, cut out thine own tongue
Lest it bewray him.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Why might not I marry?
I have not gone about, in this, to create
Any new world, or custom.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Thou art undone:
And thou hast taken that massy sheet of lead
That hid thy husband's bones, and folded it
About my heart.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Mine bleeds for't.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Thine? thy heart?
What should I name't, unless a hollow bullet
Filled with unquenchable wildfire?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: You are, in this
Too strict: and were you not my princely brother
I would say to wilful: my reputation
Is safe.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Dost thou know what reputation is
I'll tell thee, to small purpose, since th'instruction
Comes now too late:
Upon a time reputation, love, and death,
Would travel o'er the world: and it was concluded
That they should part, and take three several ways:
Death told them, they should find him in great battles:
Or cities plagued with plagues: love gives them council
To inquire for him amongst unambitious shepherds,
Where dowries were not talked of: and sometimes
Amongst quiet kindred, that had nothing left
By their dead parents: stay (Quoth reputation)
Do not forsake me: for it is my nature
If once I part from any man I meet
I am never found again: and so, for you:
You have shook hands with reputation,
And made him invisible: so fare you well.
I will never see you more.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Why should only I,
Of all the other princes of the world
Be cased-up, like a holy relic? I have youth,
And a little beauty.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: So you have some virgins,
That are witches: I will never see thee more. Exit.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: You saw this apparition.

div.stage: Enter Antonio with a pistol.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes: we are
Betrayed; how came he hither? I should turn
This, to thee, for that.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Pray sir do: and when
That you have cleft my heart, you shall read there,
Mine innocence:

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: That gallery gave him entrance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I would this terrible thing would come again,
That (Standing on my guard) I might relate
My warrantable love: ha, what means this?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: He left this with me:She shows the poniard.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And it seems, did wish
You would use it on yourself?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: His action
Seemed to intend so much.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This hath a handle to't,
As well as a point, turn it towards him,
And so fasten the keen edge, in his rank gall:
How now? who knocks? more earthquakes?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I stand
As if a mine, beneath my feet, were ready
To be blown up.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: 'Tis Bosola:

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Away,
O misery, methinks unjust actions
Should wear these masques, and curtains; and not we:
You must instantly part hence: I have fashioned it already. Ex. Ant.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: The Duke your brother is taken up in a whirl wind
Hath taken horse, and's rid post to Rome.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: So late?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: He told me, (As he mounted into th'saddle,)
You were undone.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Indeed, I am very near it.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Antonio, the master of our household
Hath dealt so falsely with me, in's accounts:
My brother stood engaged with me for money
Taken up of certain Neopolitan Jews,
And Antonio let's the bonds be forfeit.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Strange: this is cunning:

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: And hereupon
My brother's bills at Naples are protested
Against: call up our officers.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I shall. Exit.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: The place that you must fly to, is Ancona,
Hire a house there. I'll send after you
My treasure, and my jewels: our weak safety
Runs upon ingenious wheels: short syllables,
Must stand for periods: I must now accuse you
Of such a feigned crime, as Tasso calls
Magnanima mensogna: a noble lie,
'Cause it must shield our honours: hark they are coming.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Will your grace hear me?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I have got well by you: you have yielded me
A million of loss; I am like to inherit
The people's curses for your stewardship:
You had the trick, in audit time to be sick,
Till I had signed your quietus; and that cured you
Without help of a doctor. Gentlemen,
I would have this man be an example to you all:
So shall you hold my favour: I pray let him;
For has done that (Alas) you would not think of,
And (Because I intend to be rid of him)
I mean not to publish: use your fortune elsewhere.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am strongly armed to brook my overthrow,
As commonly men bear with a hard year:
I will not blame the cause on't; but do think
The necessity of my malevolent star
Procures this, not her humour: oh the inconstant,
And rotten ground of service, you may see:
'Tis e'en like him, that in a winter night
takes a long slumber, o'er a dying fire;
A-loath to part from't: yet parts thence as cold,
As when he first sat down.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: We do confiscate
(Towards the satisfying of your accounts)
All that you have.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am all yours: and 'tis very fit
All mine should be so.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: So, sir; you have your pass.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You may see (Gentlemen) what 'tis to serve
A prince with body, and soul. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.p: Here's an example, for extortion; what moisture, is drawn out of the sea, when foul weather comes, powers down, and runs into the sea again.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I would know what are your opinions
Of this Antonio.

sp.speaker: 2. Offi.
sp.l: He could not abide to see a pig's head gaping,
I thought your grace would find him a Jew:

sp.speaker: 3. Offi.
sp.l: I would you had been his officer, for your own sake.

sp.speaker: 4. Offi.
sp.l: You would have had more money.

sp.speaker: 1. Offi.
sp.l: He stopped his ears with black wool: and to (Those came a woman.
To him for money) said he was thick of hearing.

sp.speaker: 2. Offi.
sp.l: Some said he was an hermaphrodite, for he could not abide

sp.speaker: 4. Offi.
sp.l: How scurvy proud he would look, when the treasury was full:
Well, let him go:

sp.speaker: 1. Offi.
sp.l: Yes, and the chippings of the buttery fly after him,
To scour his gold chain. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Leave us: what do you think of these?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: That these are rogues; that in's prosperity,
But to have waited on his fortune, could have wished
His duty stirrup riveted through their noses:
And followed after's mule, like a bear in a ring.
Would have prostituted their daughters, to his lust:
Made their firstborn and intelligencers: thought none happy
But such as were born under his blessed planet:
And wore his livery: and do these lice drop off now?
Well, never look to have the like again;
he hath left a sort of flattring rogues, behind him,
Their doom must follow: princes pay flatterers,
In their own money: flatterers dissemble their vices,
And they dissemble their lies, that's justice:
Alas, poor gentlemen,

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Poor? he hath amply filled his coffers.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Sure he was too honest: Pluto the god of riches,
When he's sent (By Jupiter) to any man
He goes limping, to signify that wealth
That comes on god's name, comes slowly, but when he's sent
One the devil's errand, he rides post, and comes in by scuttles ▪
Let me show you, what a most unvalued jewel,
You have (In a wanton humour) thrown away,
To bless the man shall find him: he was an excellent
Courtier, and most faithful, a soldier, that thought it
As beastly to know his own value too little,
As devilish to acknowledge it too much,
Both his virtue, and form, deserved a far better fortune:
His discourse rather delighted to judge itself, then show itself.
His breast was filled with all perfection,
And yet it seemed a private whispering room.
It made so little noise of't.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: But he was basely descended.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Will you make yourself a mercenary herald,
Rather to examine men's pedigrees, than virtues?
You shall want him,
For know an honest statesman to a prince,
Is like a cedar, planted by a spring,
The spring baths the trees root, the grateful tree,
Rewards it with his shadow: you have not done so,
I would sooner swim to the Bermoothes on two politisians
Rotten bladders, tide together with an intelligencers heartstring
Then depend on so changeable a prince's favour.
Fare-thee-well (Antonio) since the malice of the world
Would needs down with thee, it cannot be said yet
That any ill happened unto thee, considering thy fall,
Was accompanied with virtue.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: O, you render me excellent music.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Say you?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: This good one that you speak of, is my husband.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Do I not dream? can this ambitious age
Have so much goodness in't, as to prefer
A man, merely for worth: without these shadows
Of wealth, and painted honours? possible?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I have had three children by him.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Fortunate lady,
For you have made your private nuptial bed
The humble, and fair seminary of peace,
No question but: many an unbeneficed scholar
Shall pray for you, for this deed, and rejoice
That some preferment in the world can yet
Arise from merit. The virgins of your land
(That have no dowries) shall hope, your example
Will raise them to rich husbands: should you want
Soldiers 'twould make the very Turks and Moors
Turn Christians, and serve you for this act.
Last, the neglected poets of your time,
(In honour of this trophy of a man,
Raised by that curious engine, (Your white hand)
Shall thank you, in your grave for't; and make that
More reverend than all the cabinets
Of living princes: for Antonio
His fame, shall likewise flow, from many a pen,
When heralds shall want coats, to sell to men.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: As I taste comfort, in this friendly speech,
So would I find concealment.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: O the secret of my prince.
Which I will wear on th'inside of my heart.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: You shall take charge of all my coin, and jewels,
And follow him, for he retires himself
To Ancona.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: So.
