sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Whether, within few days,
I mean to follow thee.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Let me think:
I would wish your grace, to feign a pilgrimage
To our lady of Loretto, (Scarce seven leagues
From fair Ancona) so may you depart
Your country, with more honour, and your flight
Will seem a princely progress, retaining
Your usual train about you.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Sir, your direction
Shall lead me, by the hand.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: In my opinion,
She were better progress to the baths
At Leuca, or go visit the spa
In Germany, for (If you will believe me)
I do not like this jesting with religion,
This feigned pilgrimage.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Thou 〈◊〉 superstitious fool,
Prepare us instantly for our departure:
Past sorrows, let us moderately lament them,
For those to come, seek wisely, to prevent them. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: A politician is the devil's quilted anvil,
He fashions all sins on him, and the blows
Are never heard, he may work in a lady's chamber,
(As here for proof) what rests, but I reveal
All to my lord? o, this base quality
Of intelligencer! why, every quality i'th' world
Prefers but gain, or commendation:
Now for this act, I am certain to be raised,
"And men that paint weeds, (To the life) are praised. Exit.

div.head: Scaena iii.
div.stage: Cardinal, Ferdinand, Mallateste, Pescara, Silvia, Delio, Bosola.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Must we turn soldier then?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The emperor,
hearing your worth that way, (Ere you attained
This reverend garment,) joins you in commission
With the right fortunate soldier, the marquis of Pescara,
And the famous Lanoy.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: He that had the honour
Of taking the French King prisoner?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The same,
Here's a plot drawn, for a new fortification,
At Naples.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: This great count Malastete, I perceive
Hath got employment?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: No employment (My lord)
A marginal note in the muster-book, that he is
A voluntary lord.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: He's no soldier?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: He has worn gunpowder, in's hollow tooth, for the toothache.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: He comes to the leaguer, with a full intent,
To eat fresh beef, and garlic, means to stay
Till the scent begone, and straight return to court.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: He hath read all the late service,
As the city chronicle relates it,
And keep two pewterers going, only to express
Battles in model.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Then he'll fight by the book.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: By the almanac, I think
To choose good days, and shun the critical ▪
That's his mistress scarf.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Yes, he protests
He would do much for that taffeta,

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: I think he would run away from a battle
To save it from taking prisoner.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: He is horribly afraid,
Gunpowder will spoil the perfume on't,

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: I saw a Dutchman break his pate once
For calling him potgun, he made his head
Have a boar in't, like a musket.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I would he had made a touchhole to't.
He is indeed a guarded sumpter-cloth
Only for the remove of the court.

sp.speaker: Pes.
sp.l: Bosola arrived? what should be the business?
Some falling out amongst the Cardinals.
These factions amongst great men, they are like
Foxes, when their heads are divided
They carry fire in their tails, and all the country
About them, goes to wrack for't.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: What's that Bosola?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: I knew him in Padua, a fantastical scholar,
Like such, who study to know how many knots was in
Hercules' club, of what colour Achilles beard was,
Or whether Hector were not troubled with the toothache,
He hath studied himself half blear-eyed, to know the
True symmetry of Caesar's nose by a shooing-horn, and this
He did to gain the name of a speculative man.

sp.speaker: Pes.
sp.l: Mark prince Ferdinand,
A very salamander lives in's eye,
To mock the eager violence of fire.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: That Cardinal hath made more bad faces with his oppression
Then ever Michael Angelo made good ones,
He lifts up's nose, like a foul porpoise before a storm,

sp.speaker: Pes.
sp.l: The lord Ferdinand laughs.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Like a deadly cannon,
That lightens ere it smokes.

sp.speaker: Pes.
sp.l: These are your true pangs of death,
The pangs of life, that struggle with great statesmen.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: In such a deformed silence, witches whisper their charms.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Doth she make religion her riding hood
To keep her from the sun, and tempest?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: That: that damns her: methinks her fault, and
Beauty blended together, show like leprosy
The whiter, the fowler: I make it a question
Whether her beggarly brats were ever christened.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: I will instantly solicit the state of Ancona
To have them banished.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: You are for Lorette?
I shall not be at your ceremony: fare you well,
Write to the Duke of Malfi, my young nephew,
She had by her first husband, and acquaint him,
With's mother's honesty.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Antonio?
A slave, that only smelled of ink, and coumptets,
And ne'er in's like, looked like a gentleman,
But in the audit time, go, go presently,
Draw me out an hundreth and fifty of our horse,
And meet me at the Fort-bridge. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena iiii.
div.stage: Two pilgrims to the shrine of our lady of Loretto.

sp.speaker: 1. Pilg.
sp.l: I have not seen a goodlier shrine than this,
Yet I have visited many.

sp.speaker: 2. Pilg.
sp.l: The Cardinal of Arragon
Is, this day to resign his Cardinal's hat,
His sister Duchess likewise is arrived
To pay her vow of pilgrimage, I expect
A noble ceremony.

sp.speaker: 1. Pilg.
sp.l: No question: — they come.

div.stage: Here the ceremony of the Cardinal's enstalment, in the habit a soldier: performed in delivering up his cross, hat, robes, and ring, at the shrine; and investing him with sword, helmet, shield and spurs: then Antonio, the Duchess, and their children, (Having presented themselves at the shrine) are (By a form of banishment in dumb-show, expressed towards them by the Cardinal, and the state of Ancona) banished: during all ceremony, this ditty is sung (To very solemn music) by divers churchmen, and then exeunt.

lg.l: Arms, and honours, deck thy story,
To thy fame's eternal glory,
Adverse fortune ever fly thee,the author disclaims this ditty to be his.
No disastrous fate come nigh-thee.
I alone will sing thy praises,
Whom to honour, virtue raises;
And thy study, that divine_is,
Bent to martial discipline-is:
Lay aside all those robes lie by thee,
Crown thy arts, with arms: they'll beautify thee.
O worthy of worthiest name, adorned in this manner,
Lead bravely thy forces on, under wars warlike banner .
Oh mayst thou prove fortunate, in all martial courses:
Guide thou still, by skill, in arts, and forces:
Victory attend thee nigh whilst fame sings loud thy powers,
Triumphant conquest crown thy head, and blessings pour down showers.

sp.speaker: 1. Pilg.
sp.l: Here's a strange turn of state, who would have thought
So great a lady, would have matched herself
Unto so mean a person? yet the Cardinal
Bears himself much too cruel.

sp.speaker: 2. Pilg.
sp.l: They are banished.

sp.speaker: 1. Pilg.
sp.l: But I would ask what power hath this state
Of Ancona to determine of a free prince?

sp.speaker: 2. Pilg.
sp.l: They are a free state sir, and her brother showed
How that the Pope forehearing of her looseness,
Hath seized into th'protection of the church
The dukedom, which she held as dowager.

sp.speaker: 1. Pil.
sp.l: But by what justice?

sp.speaker: 2. Pilg.
sp.l: Sure I think by none,
Only her brother's instigation.

sp.speaker: 1. Pilg.
sp.l: What was it, with such violence he took
Of from her finger?

sp.speaker: 2. Pil.
sp.l: 'Twas her wedding ring,
which he vowed shortly he would sacrifice
To his revenge.

sp.speaker: 1. Pilg.
sp.l: Alas Antonio,
If that a man be thrust into a well,
No matter who sets hand to't, his own weight
Will bring him sooner to th'bottom: come, let's hence.
Fortune makes this conclusion general,
"All things do help th'unhappy man to fall. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena v.
div.stage: Antonio, Duchess, children, Cariola, servants, Bosola, soldiers, with visards.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Banished Ancona?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, you see what power
Lightens in great men's breath.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Is all our train
Shrunk to this poor remainder?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: These poor men,
(Which have got little in your service) vow
To take your fortune: but your wiser buntings
Now they are fledged are gone.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: They have done wisely,
This puts me in mind of death, physicians thus,
With their hands full of money, use to give o'er
Their patients.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Right the fashion of the world,
From decayed fortunes, every flatterer shrinks,
Men cease to build, where the foundation sinks.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I had a very strange dream tonight .

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What was't?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Methought I wore my coronet of state ▪
And on a sudden all the diamonds
Were changed to pearls.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My interpretation
Is, you'll weep shortly, for to me, the pearls
do signify your tears:

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: The birds, that live i'th field
On the wild benefit of nature, live
Happier than we; for they may choose their mates,
And carol their sweet pleasures to the spring:

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: You are happily o'ertaken.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: From my brother?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Yes, from the lord Ferdinand; your brother,
All love, and safety

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Thou dost blanch mischief
Wouldst make it white: see, see; like to calm weather
At sea, before a tempest, false hearts speak fair
To those they intend most mischief.
A letter. Send Antonio to me; I want his head in a business: (A politic equivocation)
He doth not want your council, but your head;
That is, he cannot sleep till you be dead.
And here's another pitfall, that's strewed o'er
With roses: mark it, 'tis a cunning one.
I stand engaged for your husband, for several debts at Naples: let not
That trouble him, I had rather have his heart, than his money.
And I believe so too.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: What do you believe?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: That he so much distrusts my husband's love,
He will by no means believe his heart is with him
Until he see it: the devil is not cunning enough
To circumvent us in riddles.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Will you reject that noble, and free league
Of amity, and love which I present you?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Their league is like that of some politic Kings
Only to make themselves of strength, and power
To be our after-ruin: tell them so;

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: And what from you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thus tell him: I will not come.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: And what of this.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My brothers have dispersed
Bloodhounds abroad; which till I hear are muzzled
No truce, though hatched with never such politic skill
Is safe, that hangs upon our enemies will.
I'll not come at them.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: This proclaims your breeding.
Every small thing, draws a base mind to fear:
As the adamant draws iron: fare you well sir,
You shall shortly hear from's. Exit.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I suspect some ambush:
Therefore by all my love; I do conjure you
To take your eldest son, and fly towards Milan;
Let us not venture all this poor remainder
In one unlucky bottom.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You council safely:
Best of my life, farewell: since we must part
Heaven hath a hand in't: but no otherwise,
Then as some curious artist, takes in sunder
A clock, or watch, when it is out of frame
To bring't in better order.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I know not which is best,
To see you dead, or part with you: farewell boy.
Thou art happy, that thou hast not understanding
To know thy misery: for all our wit
And reading, brings us to a truer sense
Of sorrow: in the eternal church, sir,
I do hope we shall not part thus.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O, be of comfort,
Make patience a noble fortitude:
And think not how unkindly we are used:
"Man (Like to cassia) is proved best, being bruised.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Must I like to a slave-born russian,
Account it praise to suffer tyranny?
And yet (Oh heaven) thy heavy hand is in't.
I have seen my little boy, oft scourge his top,
And compared myself to't: naught made me ere go right,
But heaven's scourge-stick.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do not weep:
Heaven fashioned us of nothing: and we strive,
To bring ourselves to nothing: farewell Cariola,
And thy sweet armful: if I do never see thee more,
be a good mother to your little ones,
And save them from the tiger: fare you well.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Let me look upon you once more: for that speech
Came from a dying father: your kiss is colder
Than that I have seen an holy anchorite
Give to a dead man's skull.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My heart is turned to a heavy lump of lead,
With which I sound my danger: fare you well. Exit.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: My laurel is all withered.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Look (Madam) what a troop of armed men
Make towards us.Enter Bosola with a guard.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: O, they are very welcome:
When fortune's wheel, is overcharged with princes,
The weight makes it move swift. I would have my ruin
Be sudden: I am your adventure, am I not.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: You are, you must see your husband no more,

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: What devil art thou, that counterfeits heaven's thunder?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Is that terrible? I would have you tell me
Whether is that note worse, that frights the silly birds
Out of the corn or that which doth allure them
To the nets? you have hearkened to the last too much.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: O misery: like to a rusty o'er-charred cannon,
Shall I never fly in pieces? come: to what prison?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: To none .

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Whether then?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: To your palace.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I have heard that Charon's boat, serves to convey
All o'er the dismal lake, but brings none back again.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Your brothers mean you, safety, and pity.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Pity? with such a pity men preserve alive
Pheasants, and quails, when they are not fat enough
To be eaten.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: These are your children?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Yes:

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Can they prattle?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: No:
But I intend, since they were born accursed;
curses shall be their first language.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Fie (Madam)
Forget this base, low-fellow.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Were I a man:
I'd beat that counterfeit face, into thy other

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: One of no birth.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Say that he was born mean.
Man is most happy, when's own actions
Be arguments, and examples of his virtue.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: A barren, beggarly virtue.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I prithee who is greatest, can you tell?
Sad tales befit my woe: I'll tell you one.
A salmon, as she swam unto the sea,
Met with a dogfish; who encounters her
With this rough language: why art thou so bold
To mix thyself with our high state of floods
Being no eminent courtier, but one
That for the calmest, and fresh time o'th' year
Dost live in shallow rivers, rankest thyself
With silly smylts, and shrimps? and darest thou
Pass by our dogship, without reverence?
O (Quoth the salmon) sister, be at peace:
Thank Jupiter, we both have passed the net,
Our value never can be truly known,
Till in the fisher's basket we be shown,
I'th' market then my price may be the higher,
Even when I am nearest to the cook, and fire.
So, to great men, the moral may be stretched
Men oft are valued high, when they're most wretched.
But come: whether you please: I am armed 'gainst misery:
Bent to all sways of the oppressors' will.
There's no deep valley, but near some great hill. Ex.

div.head: Scaena. i.
div.stage: Ferdinand, Bosola, Duchess, Cariola, servants.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: How doth our sister Duchess bear herself
In her imprisonment?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Nobly: I'll describe her:
She's sad, as one long used to't: and she seems
Rather to welcome the end of misery
Then shun it: a behaviour so noble,
As gives a majesty to adversity:
You may discern the shape of loveliness
More perfect, in her tears, then in her smiles;
She will muse four hours together: and her silence,
( methinks ) expresseth more, than if she spoke.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Her melancholy seems to be fortified
With a strange disdain.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: 'Tis so: and this restraint
(Like English mastiffs, that grow fierce with tying)
Makes her too passionately apprehend
Those pleasures she's kept from.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Curse upon her:
I will no longer study in the book
Of another's heart: inform her what I told you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: All comfort to your grace;

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I will have none:
Prithee, why dost thou wrap thy poisoned pills
In gold, and sugar?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Your elder brother the lord Ferdinand
Is come to visit you: and sends you word
'Cause once he rashly made a solemn vow
Never to see you more; he comes i'th' night:
And prays you (Gently) neither torch, nor taper
Shine in your chamber: he will kiss your hand:
And reconcile himself: but, for his vow,
he dares not see you:

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: At his pleasure:
Take hence the lights: he's come.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Where are you?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Here sir:

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: This darkness suits you well.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I would ask you pardon:

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: You have it;
For I account it, the honourabl'st revenge
Where I may kill, to pardon: where are your cubs?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Whom?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Call them your children;
For though our national law, distinguish bastards
From true legitimate issue: compassionate nature
Makes them all equal.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Do you visit me for this?
You violate a sacrament o'th' church
Shall make you howl in hell for't.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: It had been well,
Could you have lived thus always: for indeed
You were too much i'th' light: but no more,
I come to seal my peace with you: here's a hand,Gives her a dead man's hand.
To which you have vowed much love: the ring upon't
You gave.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I affectionately kiss it:

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Pray do: and bury the print of it in your heart:
I will leave this ring with you, for a love-token:
And the hand, as sure as the ring: and do not doubt
But you shall have the heart too: when you need a friend
Send it to him, that owed it: you shall see
Whether he can aid you.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: You are very cold.
I fear you are not well after your travel:
Ha? lights: o horrible:

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Let her have lights enoughExit.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: What witchcraft doth he practise, that he hath left
A deadman's hand here?— here is discovered, (Behind a Travers;) the artificial figures of Antonio, and his children, appearing as if they were dead.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Look you: here's the piece, from which 'twas taken;
He doth present you this sad spectacle,
That now you know directly they are dead,
Hereafter you may (Wisely) cease to grieve
For that which cannot be recovered.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: There is not between heaven, and earth one wish
I stay for after this: it wastes me more,
Than were't my picture, fashioned out of wax,
Stuck with a magical needle, and then buried
In some foul dunghill: and yond's an excellent property
For a tyrant, which I would account mercy,

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: If they would bind me to that lifeless trunk,
And let me freeze to death.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Come, you must live.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: That's the greatest torture souls feel in hell,
In hell: that they must live, and cannot die:
Portia, I'll new kindle thy coals again,
And revive the rare, and almost dead example
Of a loving wife.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: O fie: despair? remember
You are a christian.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: The church enjoins fasting:
I'll starve myself to death.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Leave this vain sorrow;
Things being at the worst, begin to mend:
The bee when he hath shot his sting into your hand
May then play with your eyelid.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Good comfortable fellow
Persuade a wretch that's broke upon the wheel
To have all his bones new set: entreat him live,
To be executed again: who must dispatch me?
I account this world a tedious theatre,
For I do play a part in't 'gainst my will.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Come, be of comfort, I will save your life.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Indeed I have not leisure to tend so small a business.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Now, by my life, I pity you.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Thou art a fool then,
To waste thy pity on a thing so wretched
As cannot pity it: I am full of daggers:
Puff: let me blow these vipers from one.
What are you?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: One that wishes you long life.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I would thou wert hanged for the horrible curse
Thou hast given me: I shall shortly grow one
Of the miracles of pity: I'll go pray: no,
I'll go curse:

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: O fie:

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I could curse the stars.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: O fearful:

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: And those three smiling seasons of the year
Into a Russian winter: nay the world
To its first chaos.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Look you, the stars shine still:

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: O, but you must remember, my curse hath a great way to go:
Plagues, (That make lanes through largest families)
Consume them:

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Fie lady:

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Let them like tyrants
Never be remembered, but for the ill they have done:
Let all the zealous prayers of mortefied
Churchmen forget them,

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: O uncharitable:

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Let heaven, a little while, cease crowning martyrs
To punish them: go, howl them this: and say I long to bleed
, it is some mercy, when men kill with speed. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Excellent; as I would wish: she's plagued in art.
These presentations are but framed in wax.
By the curious master in that quality,
Vincentio Lauriola, and she takes them
For true substantial bodies.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Why do you do this?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: To bring her to despair.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I'faith, end here:
and go no farther in your cruelty,
Send her a penitential garment, to put on,
Next to her delicate skin, and furnish her
With beads, and prayer books.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Damn her, that body of hers,
While that my blood ran pure in't, was more worth
Then, that which thou wouldst comfort, (Called a soul)
I will send her masques of common courtesans,
Have her meat served up by bawds, and ruffians,
And ('cause she'll needs be mad) I am resolved
To remove forth the common hospital,
All the mad-folk, and place them near her lodging:
There let them practise together, sing, and dance,
And act their gambols to the full o'th' moon:
If she can sleep the better for it, let her,
Your work is almost ended.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Must I see her again?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: You must.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Never in mine own shape,
That's forfeited, by my intelligence,
And this last cruel lie: when you send me next,
The business shall be comfort.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Very likely,
Thy pity is nothing of kin to thee: Antonio,
Lurks about Milan, thou shalt shortly thither,
To feed a fire, as great as my revenge,
Which ne'er will slack, till it have spent his fuel,
"Intemperate agues, make physicians cruel. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena ii.
div.stage: Duchess, Cariola, servant, madmen, Bosola, executioners, Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: What 〈…〉 noise was that?

sp.speaker: Cari
sp.l: Of madmen (Lady) which your tyrant brother
Hath placed about your lodging: this tyranny,
I think was never practised till this hour.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Indeed I thank him: nothing but noise, and folly
Can keep me in my right wits, whereas reason
And silence, make me stark mad: sit down,
Discourse to me some dismal tragedy.

sp.speaker: Cari.
sp.l: O 'twill increase your melancholy.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Thou art deceived,
To hear of greater grief, would lessen mine,
This is a prison?

sp.speaker: Cari.
sp.l: Yes, but you shall live
To shake this durance off.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Thou art a fool,
The robin redbreast, and the nightingale,
Never live long in cages.

sp.speaker: Cari.
sp.l: Pray dry your eyes.
What think you of madam?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Of nothing :
When I muse thus, I sleep.

sp.speaker: Cari.
sp.l: Like a madman, with your eyes open?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Dost thou think we shall know one another,
In th'other world?

sp.speaker: Cari.
sp.l: Yes, out of question.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: O that it were possible we might
But hold some two days' conference with the dead.
From them, I should learn somewhat I am sure
I never shall know here: I'll tell thee a miracle,
I am not mad yet, to my cause of sorrow.
Th'heaven o'er my head, seems made of molten brass.
The earth of flaming sulphur, yet I am not mad:
I am acquainted with sad misery,
As the tanned galleyslave, is with his oar,
Necessity makes me suffer constantly,
And custom makes it easy, who do I look like now?

sp.speaker: Cari.
sp.l: Like to your picture in the gallery,
A deal of life in show, but none in practice:
Or rather like some reverend monument
Whose ruins, are even pitied.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Very proper:
And fortune seems only to have her eyesight,
To behold my tragedy: how now,
What noise is that?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: I am come to tell you,
your brother hath intended you some sport:
A great physician, when the Pope was sick
Of a deep melancholy, presented him
With several sorts of madmen, which wild object
(Being full of change, and sport,) forced him to laugh,
And so th'impostume broke: the self same cure,
The Duke intends on you.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Let them come in.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: There's a mad lawyer, and a secular priest,
A doctor that hath forfeited his wits
By jealousy: an astrologian,
That in his works, said such a day o'th month,
Should be the day of doom; and failing of't,
Ran mad: an English tailor, crazed i'th' brain,
With the study of new fashion: a gentleman usher
Quite beside himself, with care to keep in mind,
The number of his lady's salutations;
Or how do you, she employed him in each morning:
A farmer too, (An excellent knave in grain)
Mad, 'cause he was hindered transportation,
And let one broker, (That's mad) lose to these,
You'd think the devil were among them.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Sit Cariola: let them lose when you please,
For I am chained to endure all your tyranny.

div.stage: Here (By a madman) this song is sung, to a dismal kind of music.

lg.l: O let us howl, some heavy note,
Some deadly-dogged howl,
Sounding, as from the threatening throat,
Of beasts, and fatal fowl.
As ravens, screech-owls, bulls, and bears,
We'll bill, and bawl our parts,
Till yerk some noise have cloyed your ears,
And corrosived your hearts.
At last whenas our choir wants breath,
Our bodies being blessed,
We'll sing like swans, to welcome death,
And die in love and rest.

sp.speaker: 1. Madman.
sp.p: Doomsday not come yet? I'll draw it nearer by a perspective, or make a glass, that shall set all the world on fire upon an instant: I cannot sleep, my pillow is stuffed with a litter of porcupines.

sp.speaker: 2. Mad.
sp.p: Hell is a mere glass-house, where the devils are continually blowing up women's souls, on hollow irons, and the fire never goes out.

sp.speaker: 3. Mad.
sp.l: I will lie with every woman in my parish the tenth night:
I will tithe them over like haycocks.

sp.speaker: 4. Mad.
sp.l: Shall my apothecary outgo me, because I am a
Cuckold? I have found out his roguery: he makes alum
Of his wife's urine, and sells it to Puritaines, that have sore
Throats with overstraining.

sp.speaker: 1. Mad.
sp.l: I have skill in heraldry.
Hast?
You do give for your crest, a woodcock's head, with the
Brains picked out on't, you are a very ancient gentleman.
Greek is turned Turk, we are only to be saved by the
Helvetian translation.
Come on sir, I will lay the law to you.
O, rather lay a corazive, the law will eat to the bone.
He that drinks but to satisfy nature is damned.
If I had my glass here, I would show a sight should make
All the women here, call me mad doctor.
What's he, a rope-maker?
No, no, no, a snuffling knave, that while he shows the
Tombs, will have his hand in a wench's placket.
Woe, to the caroche, that brought home my wife from
The masque, at three o'clock in the morning, it had a large
Featherbed in it.
I have paired the devil's nails forty times, roasted them
In ravens eggs, and cured agues with them.
Get me three hundred milch bats, to make possets ▪
To procure sleep.
All the college may throw their caps at me, I have made a
Soap-boiler costive, it was my masterpiece:— here the dance consisting of 8. Madmen, with music answerable there unto, after which, Bosola (Like an old man) enters.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Is he mad to?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Pray question him: I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I am come to make thy tomb.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Ha, my tomb?
Thou speak'st, as if I lay upon my death bed,
Gasping for breath: dost thou perceive me sick?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Yes, and the more dangerously, since thy sickness is insensible.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Thou art not mad sure, dost know me?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Who am I?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Thou art a box of wormseed at best, but a salvatory
Of green mummy: what's this flesh? A little curdled milk,
Fantastical puff-paste: our bodies are weaker than those
Paper prisons boys use to keep flies in: more contemptible:
Since ours is to preserve earthworms: didst thou ever see
A lark in a cage? such is the soul in the body: this world
Is like her little turf of grass, and the heaven o'er our heads,
Like her looking glass, only gives us a miserable knowledge
Of the small compass of our prison.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Am not I, thy Duchess?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Thou art some great woman sure, for riot begins to sit on thy
Forehead (Clad in grey hairs) twenty years sooner, than on a
Merry milk maids. Thou sleepest worse, than if a mouse
Should be forced to take up her lodging in a cat's ear:
A little infant, that breeds it's teeth, should it lie with thee, would
Cry out, as if thou wert the more unquiet bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I am Duchess of Malfi still.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: That makes thy sleeps so broken:
"Glories (Like glowworms) afar off, shine bright,
But looked too near, have neither heat, nor light.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Thou art very plain.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: My trade is to flatter the dead, not the living
I am a tomb-maker.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: And thou comest to make my tomb?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Let me be a little merry,
Of what stuff wilt thou make it?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Nay, resolve me first, of what fashion?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Why, do we grow fantastical in our deathbed?
Do we affect fashion in the grave?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Most ambitiously: princes images on their tombs,
Do not lie, as they were wont, seeming to pray,
Up to heaven: but with their hands under their cheeks,
(As if they died of the toothache) they are not carved
With their eyes, fixed upon the stars; but as their
Minds were wholly bent upon the world,
The selfsame way they seem to turn their faces.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Let me know fully therefore the effect
Of this thy dismal preparation,
This talk, fit for a charnel?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Now, I shall,
Here is a present from your princely brothers,A coffin, cords, and a bell.
And may it arrive welcome, for it brings
Last benefit, last sorrow.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Let me see it,
I have so much obedience, in my blood,
I wish it in their veins, to do them good.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: This is your last presence chamber.

sp.speaker: Cari.
sp.l: O my sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Peace, it affrights not me.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I am the common bellman,
That usually is sent to condemned persons ▪
The night before they suffer:

sp.speaker: Duch
sp.l: Even now thou saidst,
Thou wast a tomb-maker?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: 'Twas to bring you
By degrees to mortification: listen.
Hark, now every thing is still,
The screech-owl, and the whistler shrill,
Call upon our dame, aloud,
And bid her quickly don her shroud:
much you had of land and rent,
Your length in clay's now competent.
A long war, disturbed your mind,
Here your perfect peace is signed,
Of what is't, fools make such vain keeping?
Sin their conception, their birth, weeping:
Their life, a general mist of error,
Their death, a hideous storm of terror,
Strew your hair, with powders sweet:
Don clean linen, bathe your feet,
And (The foul fiend more to check)
A crucifix let bless your neck,
'Tis now full tide, between night, and day,
End your groan, and come away.

sp.speaker: Cari.
sp.l: Hence villains, tyrants, murderers: alas!
What will you do with my lady? call for help.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: To whom, to our next neighbours? they are mad-folks.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Remove that noise.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Farewell Cariola,
In my last will, I have not much to give
A many hungry guests, have fed upon me,
Thine will be a poor reversion.

sp.speaker: Cari.
sp.l: I will die with her.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I praythee look thou givest my little boy
Some syrup, for his cold, and let the girl
Say her prayers, ere she sleep. Now what you please,
What death?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Strangling, here are your executioners.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I forgive them:
The apoplexy, catarrh, or cough o'th lungs,
Would do as much as they do.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Doth not death fright you?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Who would be afraid on't?
Knowing to meet such excellent company
In th'other world.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Yet, methinks ,
The manner of your death should much afflict you,
this cord should terrify you?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Not a whit,
What would it pleasure me, to have my throat cut
With diamonds? or to be smothered
With Cassia? or to be shot to death, with pearls?
I know death hath ten thousand several doors
For men to take their exits: and 'tis found
They go on such strange geometrical hinges,
You may open them both ways: any way, (For heaven's sake)
So I were out of your whispering: tell my brothers,
That I perceive death, (Now I am well awake wake)
Best gift is, they can give, or I can take,
I would fain put off my last woman's-fault,
I'd not be tedious to you.

sp.speaker: Ex●c.
sp.l: We are ready.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Dispose my breath, how please you, but my body
Bestow upon my women, will you?

sp.speaker: Executioner
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Pull, and pull strongly, for your able strength,
Most pull down heaven upon me:
Yet stay, heaven gates are not so highly arched
As prince's palaces, they that enter there
Must go upon their knees: come violent death,
Serve for mandragora, to make me sleep;
Go tell my brothers, when I am laid out,They strangle her.
They then may feed in quiet.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Where's the waiting woman?
Fetch her: some other strangle the children:
Look you, there sleeps your mistress.

sp.speaker: Cari.
sp.l: O you are damned
Perpetually for this: my turn is next,
Is't not so ordered?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Yes, and I am glad
You are so well prepared for't.

sp.speaker: Cari.
sp.l: You are deceived sir,
I am not prepared for't, I will not die,
I will first come to my answer; and know
How I have offended.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Come, dispatch her:
You kept her counsel, now you shall keep ours.

sp.speaker: Cari.
sp.l: I will not die, I must not, I am contracted
to a young gentleman.

sp.speaker: Executioner
sp.l: Here's your wedding ring.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Let me but speak with the Duke: I'll discover
Treason to his person.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Delays: throttle her.

sp.speaker: Executioner
sp.l: She bites: and scratches:

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: If you kill me now
I am damned: I have not been at confession
This two years:

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: When.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: I am quick with child.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Why then,
Your credit's saved: bear her in toth' next room:
Let this lie still.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Is she dead?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: She is what
You'd have her: but here begin your pity,Shows the children strangled .
Alas, how have these offended?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: The death
Of young wolves, is never to be pitied.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Fix your eye here:

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Constantly.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Do you not weep?
Other sins, only speak; murder shrieks out:
The element of water, moistens the earth,
But blood flies onwards, and bedews the heavens.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Cover her face: mine eyes dazzle she died young.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I think not so: her infelicity
Seemed to have years too many.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: She, and I were twins:
And should I die this instant, I had lived
Her time to a minute.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: It seems she was born first:
You have bloodily approved the ancient truth,
That kindred commonly do worse agree
Then remote strangers.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Let me see her face again;
Why didst not thou pity her: what an excellent
Honest man, mightst thou have been
If thou hadst born her to some sanctuary?
Or (Bold in a good cause) opposed thyself
With thy advanced sword above thy head,
Between her innocence, and my revenge?
I bade thee, when I was distracted of my wits ▪
Go kill my dearest friend, and thou hast don't.
For let me but examine well the cause;
What was the meanness of her match to me ▪
Only I must confess, I had a hope
(Had she continued widow) to have gained
An infinite mass of treasure by her death:
And that was the main cause; her marriage,
That drew a stream of gall, quite through my heart;
For thee, (As we observe in tragedies
That a good actor many times is cursed
For playing a villain's part) I hate thee for't:
And (For my sake) say thou hast done much ill, well:

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Let me quicken your memory: for I perceive
You are falling into ingratitude: I challenge
The reward due to my service.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I'll tell thee,
What I'll give thee,

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Do:

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I'll give thee a pardon
For this murder:

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Hah?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Yes: and 'tis
The largest bounty I can study to do thee.
By what authority didst thou execute
This bloody sentence?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: By yours

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Mine? was I her judge?
Did any ceremonial form of law,
Doom her to not-being? did a complete jury
Deliver her conviction up i'th court?
Where shalt thou find this judgement registered
Unless in hell? See: like a bloody fool
Thou'st forfeited thy life, and thou shalt die for't.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: The office of justice is perverted quite
When one thief hangs another: who shall dare
To reveal this:

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: O, I'll tell thee:
the wolf shall find her grave, and scrape it up:
Not to devour the corpses, but to discover
The horrid murder.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: You; not I shall quake for't.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Leave me:

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I will first receive my pension.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: You are a villain:

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: When your ingratitude
Is judge, I am so;

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: O horror!
That not the fear of him, which binds the devils
Can prescribe man obedience.
Never look upon me more.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Why fare thee well ▪
Your brother, and yourself, are worthy men;
You have a pair of hearts, are hollow graves,
Rotten, and rotting others: and your vengeance,
(Like two-chained bullets) still goes arm in arm,
You may be brothers: for treason, like the plague,
Doth take much in a blood: I stand like one
That long hath taken a sweet, and golden dream.
I am angry with myself, now that I wake.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Get thee into some unknown part o'th ▪ world
That I may never see thee.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Let me know
Wherefore I should be thus neglected? sir,
I served your tyranny: and rather strove,
To satisfy yourself, than all the world;
And though I loathed the evil, yet I loved
You that did council it: and rather sought
To appear a true servant, than an honest man.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I'll go hunt the badger by owl-light:
'Tis a deed of darkness. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: He's much distracted: off my painted honour,
While with vain hopes, our faculties we tire,
We seem to sweat in yce, and freeze in fire;
What would I do, were this to do again?
I would not change my peace of conscience
For all the wealth of Europe: she stirs; here's life:
Return (Fair soul) from darkness, and lead mine
Out of this sensible hell: she's warm, she breathes:
upon thy pale lips I will melt my heart
To store them with fresh colour: who's there?
Some cordial drink: alas! I dare not call:
So pity, would destroy pity: her eye opens,
And heaven in it, seems to open, (That late was shut)
To take me up to merry.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Antonio.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Yes (Madam) he is living,
The dead bodies you saw, were but feigned statues;
He's reconciled to your brothers: the Pope hath wrought
The atonement.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Mercy.She dies,

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: O, she's gone again: there the cords of life broke:
O sacred innocence, that sweetly sleeps
On turtles feathers: whilst a guilty conscience
Is a black register, wherein is writ
All our good deeds, and bad: a perspective
That shows us hell; that we cannot be suffered
To do good when we have a mind to it?
This is manly sorrow:
These tears, I am very certain, never grew
In my mother's milk. My estate is sunk
Below the degree of fear: where were
These penitent fountains, while she was living?
O, they were frozen up: here is a sight
As direful to my soul, as is the sword
Unto a wretch hath slain his father: come, I'll bear thee hence.
And execute thy last will; that's deliver
Thy body to the reverend dispose
Of some good women: that the cruel tyrant
Shall not deny me: then I'll post to Milan,
Where some what I will speedily enact
Worth my dejection. Exit.

div.head: Scaena. i.
div.stage: Antonio, Delio, Pescara, Julia.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What think you of my hope of reconcilement
To the Aragonian brothers?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: I misdoubt it
For though they have sent their letters of safe conduct
For your repair to Milan, they appear
But nets, to entrap you: the marquis of Pescara,
Under whom you hold certain land in escheat,
Much 'gainst his noble nature, hath been moved
To seize those lands, and some of his dependants
Are at this instant, making it their suit
To be invested in your revenues.
I cannot think, they mean well to your life,
That do deprive you of your means of life,
Your living.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You are still an heretic.
To any safety, I can shape myself.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Here comes the marquis: I will make myself
Petitioner for some part of your land,
To know whether it is flying.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I pray do.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Sir, I have a suit to you.

sp.speaker: Pesc.
sp.l: To me.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: An easy one:
There is the citadel of st. Bennet,
With some demesnes, of late in the possession
Of Antonio Bologna, please you bestow them on me?

sp.speaker: Pesc.
sp.l: You are my friend: but this is such a suit,
Nor fit for me to give, nor you to take.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: No sir?

sp.speaker: Pesc.
sp.l: I will give you ample reason for't,
Soon in private: here's the Cardinal's mistress.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: My lord, I am grown your poor petitioner,
And should be an ill beggar, had I not
A great man's letter, here (The Cardinals)
To court you in my favour.

sp.speaker: Pesc.
sp.l: He entreats for you
The citadel of saint Bennet, that belonged
To the banished Bologna.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Yes:

sp.speaker: Pesc.
sp.l: I could not have thought of a friend, I could
Rather pleasure with it: 'tis yours:

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Sir, I thank you:
And he shall know how doubly I am engaged
Both in your gift, and speediness of giving,
Which makes your grant, the greater. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How they fortify
Themselves with my ruin?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Sir: I am
Little bound to you:

sp.speaker: Pesc.
sp.l: Why.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Because you denied this suit, to me, and gav't
To such a creature.

sp.speaker: Pesc.
sp.l: Do you know what it was?
It was Antonio's land: not forfeited
By course of law; but ravished from his throat
By the Cardinal's entreaty: it were not fit
I should bestow so main a piece of wrong
Upon my friend: 'tis a gratification
Only due to a strumpet: for it is injustice;
Shall I sprinkle the pure blood of innocents
To make those followers, I call my friends
Look ruddier upon me? I am glad
This land, (Taken from the owner by such wrong)
Returns again unto so foul an use,
As salary for his lust. Learn, (Good Delio)
To ask noble things of me, and you shall find
I'll be a noble giver.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: You instruct me well:

sp.speaker: Ant
sp.l: Why, here's a man, now, would fright impudence
From sawciest beggars.

sp.speaker: Pesc.
sp.l: Prince ferdinand's come to Milan
Sick (As they give out) of an apoplexy:
But some say, 'tis a frenzy; I am going
To visit him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis a noble old fellow:

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: What course do you mean to take, Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This night, I mean to venture all my fortune
(Which is no more, than a poor lingering life)
To the Cardinal's worst of malice: I have got
Private access to his chamber: and intend
To visit him, about the mid of night.
(As once his brother did our noble Duchess.)
It may be that the sudden apprehension
Of danger (For I'll go in mine own shape)
When he shall see it freight with love, and duty,
May draw the poison out of him, and work
A friendly reconcilement; if it fail;
Yet, it shall rid me of this infamous calling,
For better fall once, then be ever falling.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: I'll second you in all danger: and ( howe'er )
My life keeps rank with yours

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You are still my loved, and best friend. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena. Ii.
div.stage: Pescara, a doctor, Ferdinand, Cardinal, Malateste, Bosola, Julia.

sp.speaker: Pesc.
sp.l: Now doctor; may I visit your patient?

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.l: If't please your lordship: but he's instantly
To take the air here in the gallery,
By my direction.

sp.speaker: Pesc.
sp.l: Prithee, what's his disease?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: A very pestilent disease (My lord)
They call lycanthropia.

sp.speaker: Pesc.
sp.l: What's that?
I need a dictionary to't.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: I'll tell you:
In those that are possessed with't there o'erflows
Such melancholy humour, they imagine
Themselves to be transformed into wolves,
Steal forth to churchyards in the dead of night,
And dig dead bodies up: as two nights since
One met the Duke, about midnight in a lane
Behind st. marks church, with the leg of a man
upon his shoulder; and he howled fearfully:
Said he was a wolf: only the difference
Was, a wolf's skin was hairy on the outside,
His on the inside: bade them take their swords,
Rip up his flesh, and try: straight I was sent for,
And having ministered to him, found his grace
Very well recovered.

sp.speaker: Pesc.
sp.l: I am glad on't,

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Yet not without some fear
Of a relapse: if he grow to his fit again
I'll go a nearer way to work with him
Then ever Paracelsus dreamed of: if
They'll give me leave I'll buffet his madness out of him.
Stand aside: he comes.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Leave me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Why doth your lordship love this solitariness?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Eagles commonly fly alone: they are crows, daws, and
Starlings that flock together: look, what's that,
Follows me?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Nothing (My lord)

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Yes:

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: 'Tis your shadow.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Stay it, let it not haunt me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Impossible; if you move, and the sun shine:

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I will throttle it.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: O, my lord: you are angry with nothing.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: You are a fool:
How is't possible I should catch my shadow
Unless I fall upon't? When I go to hell,
I mean to carry a bribe: for look you
Good gifts evermore make away, for the worst persons

sp.speaker: Pesc.
sp.l: Rise good my lord.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I am studying the art of patience.

sp.speaker: Pesc.
sp.l: 'Tis a noble virtue;

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: To drive six snails before me, from this town
To Mosco; neither use goad, nor whip to them,
But let them take their own time: (The patientest man i'th'world
Match me for an experiment) and I'll crawl after
Like a sheep-biter.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Force him up.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Use me well, you were best:
What I have done, I have done: I'll confess nothing .

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.l: Now let me come to him: are you mad
(My lord?) are you out of your princely wits?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: Pesc.
sp.l: Your doctor .

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Let me have his beard sawed off, and his eye
Brows filed more civil.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: I must do mad tricks with him,
For that's the only way on't. I have brought
Your grace a salamander's skin, to keep you
For sun-burning.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I have cruel sore eyes.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: The white of a cockatrice-egg is present remedy.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Let it be a new laid one, you were best:
Hide me from him: physicians are like Kings,
They brook no contradiction.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Now he begins to fear me,
Now let me alone with him.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: How now, put off your gown?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Let me have some forty urinals filled with rose-water:
He, and I'll go pelt one another with them,
Now he begins to fear me: can you fetch a frisk, sir?
Let him go, let him go upon my peril:
I find by his eye, he stands in awe of me,
I'll make him, as tame as a dormouse.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Can you fetch your frisks, sir: I will stamp him into a cullis:
Flay off his skin, to cover one of the anatomies,
This rogue hath set i'th' cold yonder, in barber-chyrurgeons hall:
Hence, hence, you are all of you, like beasts for sacrifice,
There's nothing left of you, but tongue, and belly,
Flattery, and lechery.

sp.speaker: Pes.
sp.l: Doctor, he did not fear you thoroughly.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: True, I was somewhat too forward.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Mercy upon me, what a fatal judgement
Hath fallen upon this Ferdinand?

sp.speaker: Pes.
sp.l: Knows your grace
What accident hath brought unto the prince,
This strange distraction?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: I must feign somewhat: thus they say it grew.
You have heard it rumoured for these many years,
None of our family dies, but there is seen
The shape of an old woman, which is given
By tradition, to us, to have been murdered
By her nephews, for her riches: such a figure
One night (As the prince sat up late at's book)
Appeared to him, when crying out for help,
The gentlemen of's chamber, found his grace
All on a cold sweat, altered much in face
And language: since which apparition,
He hath grown worse, and worse, and I much fear
He cannot live.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Sir, I would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Pes.
sp.l: We'll leave your grace,
Wishing to the sick prince, our noble lord,
All health of mind, and body.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: You are most welcome:
Are you come? so: this fellow must not know
By any means I had intelligence
In our Duchess death: for (Though I counselled it,)
The full of all th'engagement seemed to grow
From Ferdinand: now sir, how fares our sister?
I do not think but sorrow makes her look
Like to an oft-dyed garment: she shall now
Taste comfort from me: why do you look so wildly?
O, the fortune of your master here, the prince
Dejects you, but be you of happy comfort:
If you'll do on thing for me, I'll entreat
Though he had a cold tombstone o'er his bones,
I'd make you what you would be.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Any thing,
Give it me in a breath, and let me sly to't:
They that think long, small expedition win,
For musing much o'th' end, cannot begin.

sp.speaker: Iu●.
sp.l: Sir, will you come in to supper?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: I am busy, leave me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What an excellent shape hath that fellow? Exit.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: 'Tis thus: Antonio lurks here in Milan,
Inquire him out, and kill him: while he lives,
Our sister cannot marry, and I have thought
Of an excellent match for her: do this, and style me
Thy advancement.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: But by what means shall I find him out?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: There is a gentleman, called Delio
Here in the camp, that hath been long approved
His loyal friend: set eye upon that fellow,
Follow him to mass, may be Antonio,
Although he do account religion
But a school-name, for fashion of the world,
May accompany him, or else go inquire out
Delio's confessor, and see if you can bribe
Him to reveal it: there are a thousand ways
A man might find to trace him: as to know,
What fellows haunt the Jews, for taking up
Great sums of money, for sure he's in want,
Or else to go to th'picture-makers, and learn
Who brought her picture lately, some of these
Happily may take —

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Well, I'll not freeze i'th' business,
I would see that wretched thing, Antonio
Above all sights i'th' world.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Do, and be happy. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: This fellow doth breed bazalisques in's eyes,
He's nothing else, but murder: yet he seems
Not to have notice of the Duchess death:
'Tis his cunning: I must follow his example,
There cannot be a surer way to trace,
Than that of an old fox.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: So, sir, you are well met.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Nay, the doors are fast enough:
Now sir, I will make you confess your treachery.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Treachery?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Yes, confess to me
Which of my women 'twas you hired, to put
Love-powder into my drink?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Love powder?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Yes, when I was at Malfi,
Why should I fall in love with such a face else?
I have already suffered for thee so much pain,
The only remedy to do me good,
Is to kill my longing.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Sure your pistol holds
Nothing but perfumes, or kissing comfits: excellent lady,
You have a pretty way on't to discover
Your longing: come, come, I'll disarm you,
And arm you thus, yet this is wondrous strange.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Compare thy form, and my eyes together,
You'll find my love no such great miracle: now you'll say,
I am wanton: this nice modesty, in ladies
Is but a troublesome familiar,
That haunts them.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Know you me, I am a blunt soldier.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The better,
Sure, there wants fire, where there are no lively sparks
Of roughness.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: And I want compliment.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why ignorance in courtship cannot make you do amiss,
If you have a heart to do well.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: You are very fair.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Nay, if you lay beauty to my charge,
I must plead unguilty.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Your bright eyes
Carry a quiver of darts in them, sharper
Than sunbeams.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You will mar me with commendation,
Put yourself to the charge of courting me,
Whereas now I woo you.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I have it, I will work upon this creature,
Let us grow most amorously familiar:
If the great Cardinal now should see me thus,
Would he not count me a villain?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No, he might count me a wanton,
Not lay a scruple of offence on you:
For if I see, and steal a diamond,
The fault is not i'th' ston, but in me the thief,
that purloins it: I am sudden with you,
We that are great women of pleasure, use to cut off
These uncertain wishes, and unquiet longings,
And in an instant join the sweet delight
And the pretty excuse together: had you been in'th'street,
Under my chamber window, even there
I should have courted you.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: O, you are an excellent lady.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Bid me do somewhat for you presently,
To express I love you.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I will, and if you love me,
Fail not to effect it: the Cardinal is grown wondrous melancholy,
Demand the cause, let him not put you off,
With feigned excuse, discover the main ground on't.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why would you know this?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I have depended on him,
And I hear that he is fallen in some disgrace
With the emperor, if he be, like the mice
That forsake falling houses, I would shift
To other dependence.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You shall not need follow the wars,
I'll be your maintenance.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: And I your loyal servant,
But I cannot leave my calling.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Not leave an
Ungrateful general, for the love of a sweet lady?
You are like some, cannot sleep in featherbeds,
But must have blocks for their pillows.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Will you do this?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Cunningly.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Tomorrow I'll expect th'intelligence.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Tomorrow? get you into my cabinet,
You shall have it with you: do not delay me,
No more than I do you: I am like one
That is condemned: I have my pardon promised.
But I would see it sealed: go, get you in,
You shall see me wind my tongue about his heart,
Like a skein of silk.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Where are you?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Let none upon your lives
Have conference with the prince Ferdinand,
Unless I know it: in this distraction
He may reveal the murder:
Yond's my lingering consumption:
I am weary of her; and by any means
Would be quit off.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How now, my lord?
What ails you?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O, you are much altered:
Come, I must be your secretary, and remove
This lead from off your bosom, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: I may not tell you ▪

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Are you so far in love with sorrow,
You cannot part, with part of it? or think you
I cannot love your grace, when you are sad,
As well as merry? or do you suspect
I, that have been a secret to your heart,
These many winters, cannot be the same
Unto your tongue?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Satisfy thy longing,
The only way to make thee keep my council,
Is not to tell thee.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Tell your echo this,
Or flatterers, that (Like echoes) still report
What they hear (Though most imperfect) and not me:
For, if that you be true unto yourself,
I'll know.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Will you rack me?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No, judgement shall
Draw it from you: it is an equal fault,
To tell ones secrets, unto all, or none.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: The first argues folly.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: But the last tyranny.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Very well, why imagine I have committed
Some secret deed, which I desire the world
May never hear of?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Therefore may not I know it?
You have concealed for me, as great a sin
as adultery: sir, never was occasion
For perfect trial of my constancy
Till now: sir, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: You'll repent it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: It hurries thee to ruin: I'll not tell thee,
Be well advised, and think what danger 'tis
To receive a prince's secrets: they that do,
Had need have their breasts hooped with adamant
To contain them: I pray thee yet be satisfied,
Examine thine own frailty, 'tis more easy
To tie knots, then unloose them: 'tis a secret
That (Like a lingering poison) may chance lie
Spread in thy veins, and kill thee seven year hence .

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Now you dally with me.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: No more, thou shalt know it.
By my appointment, the great Duchess of Malfi,
And two of her young children, four nights since
Were strangled.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O heaven! (Sir) what have you done?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: How now? how settles this? think you your
Bosom will be a grave, dark and obscure enough
For such a secret?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You have undone yourself (Sir.)

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: It lies not in me to conceal it.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: No? come, I will swear you to't upon this book .

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Most religiously.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Kiss it.
Now you shall never utter it, thy curiosity
Hath undone thee: thou'rt poisoned with that book,
Because I knew thou couldst not keep my council,
I have bound the to't by death.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: For pity's sake, hold.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Ha, Bosola?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I forgive you,
This equal piece of justice you have done:
For I betrayed your council to that fellow,
He over heard it; that was the cause I said
It lay not in me, to conceal it.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: O foolish woman,
couldst not thou have poisoned him?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis weakness,
Too much to think what should have been done,
I go, I know not whither.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Wherefore comest thou hither?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: That I might find a great man, (Like yourself,)
Not out of his wits (As the lord Ferdinand)
To remember my service.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: I'll have thee hewed in pieces.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Make not yourself such a promise of that life
Which is not yours, to dispose of.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Who placed thee here.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Her lust, as she intended.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Very well, now you know me for your fellow murderer .

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: And wherefore should you lay fair marble colours,
Upon your rotten purposes to me?
Unless you imitate some that do plot great treasons,
And when they have done, go hide themselves i'th' graves,
Of those were actors in't?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: No more,
There is a fortune attends thee.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Shall I go sue to fortune any longer?
'Tis the fool's pilgrimage.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: I have honours in store for thee.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: There are a many ways that conduct to seeming
Honour, and some of them very dirty ones.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Throw to the devil
Thy melancholy, the fire burns well,
What need we keep a stirring of 〈◊〉 and make
A greater smoother? thou wilt kill Antonio?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Take up that body.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I think I shall
Shortly grow the common bear, for churchyards?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: I will allow thee some dozen of attendants,
To aid thee in the murder.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: O, by no means,
Physicians that apply horse-leeches to any rank swelling,
Use to cut of their tails, that the blood may run through them
the faster: let me have no train, when I go to shed blood,
Lest it make me have a greater, when I ride to the gallows.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Come to me after midnight, to help to remove that body
To her own lodging: I'll give out she died o'th' plague;
'Twill breed the less enquiry after her death.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Where's Castruchio, her husband?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: He's rod to Naples to take possession
Of Antonio's citadel.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Believe me, you have done a very happy turn.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Fail not to come: there is the master-key
Of our lodgings: and by that you may conceive
What trust I plant in you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: You shall find me ready.
O poor Antonio, though nothing be so needful
To thy estate, as pity, yet I find
Nothing so dangerous: I must look to my footing;
In such slippery ice-pavements, men had need
To be frost-nailed well: they may break their necks else.
The president's here afore me: how this man
Bears up in blood? seems fearless? why, 'tis well:
Security some men call the suburbs of hell,
Only a dead wall between. Well (Good Antonio)
I'll seek thee out; and all my care shall be
To put thee into safety from the reach
Of these most cruel biters, that have got
Some of thy blood already. It may be,
I'll join with thee, in a most just revenge.
The weakest arm is strong enough, that strikes
With the sword of justice: still methinks the Duchess
Haunts me: there, there ▪ 'tis nothing but my melancholy.
O penitence, let me truly taste thy cup.
That throws men down, only to raise them up. Exit.

div.head: Scaena. Iii.
div.stage: Antonio, Delio, echo, (From the Duchess grave.)

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Yond's the Cardinal's window: this fortification
Grew from the ruins of an ancient abbey:
And to yond side o'th' river, lies a wall
(Piece of a cloister) which in my opinion
Gives the best echo, that you ever heard;
So hollow, and so dismal, and withal
So plain in the distinction of our words,
That many have supposed it is a spirit
That answers.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I do love these ancient ruins ▪
We never tread upon them, but we set
Our foot upon some reverend history ▪
And questionless, here in this open court
(Which now lies naked to the injuries
Of stormy weather) some men lie interred
Loved the church so well, and gave so largely to't,
They thought it should have canopied their bones
Till doomsday: but all things have their end:
Churches, and cities (Which have diseases like to men)
Must have like death that we have.

sp.speaker: Echo.
sp.l: Like death that we have.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Now the echo hath caught you:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It groaned ( methought ) and gave
A very deadly accent?

sp.speaker: Echo.
sp.l: Deadly accent.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: I told you 'twas a pretty one: you may make it
A huntsman, or a falconer, a musician,
Or a thing of sorrow.

sp.speaker: Echo.
sp.l: A thing of sorrow.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I sur●● that suits it best.

sp.speaker: Echo.
sp.l: That suits it best.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis very like my wife's voice.

sp.speaker: Echo.
sp.l: Ay, wives-voice.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Come: let's us walk farther from't:
I would not have you go toth' Cardinals tonight :
Do not.

sp.speaker: Echo.
sp.l: Do not.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Wisdom doth not more moderate, wasting sorrow
Then time: take time for't: be mindful of thy safety.

sp.speaker: Echo.
sp.l: Be mindful of thy safety.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Necessity compels me:
Make scrutiny throughout the passes
Of your own life; you'll find it impossible
To fly your fate.
O fly your fate.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Hark: the dead stones seem to have pity on you
And give you good counsel.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Echo, I will not talk with thee;
For thou art a dead thing.

sp.speaker: Echo.
sp.l: Thou art a dead thing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My Duchess is asleep now,
And her litle-ones, I hope sweetly: o heaven
Shall I never see her more?

sp.speaker: Echo.
sp.l: Never see her more:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I marked not one repetition of the echo
But that: and on the sudden, a clear light
Presented me a face folded in sorrow.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Your fancy; merely.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come: I'll be out of this ague;
For to live thus, is not indeed to live:
It is a mockery, and abase of life,
I will not henceforth save myself by halves,
Lose all, or nothing.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Your own virtue save you:
I'll fetch your eldest son; and second you:
It may be that the sight of his own blood
Spread in so sweet a figure, may beget
The more compassion.
however , fare you well:
Though in our miseries, fortune have a part,
Yet, in our noble sufferings, she hath none,
Contempt of pain, that we may call our own. Exe.

div.head: Scaena. Iiii.
div.stage: Cardinal, Pescara, Malateste, Rodorigo, Grisolan, Bosola, Ferdinand, Antonio, servant.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: You shall not watch tonight by the sick prince,
His grace is very well recovered.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Good my lord suffer us.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: O, by no means:
The noise, and change of object in his eye,
Doth more distract him: I pray, all to bed,
And though you hear him in his violent fit ▪
Do not rise, I entreat you.

sp.speaker: Pes.
sp.l: So sir, we shall not,

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Nay, I must have you promise
Upon your honours, for I was enjoined to't
By himself; and he seemed to urge it sensibly.

sp.speaker: Pes.
sp.l: Let out honours bind this trifle.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Nor any of your followers.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Neither.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: It may be to make trial of your promise
When he's asleep , myself will rise, and feign
Some of his mad tricks, and cry out for help,
And feign myself in danger.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: If your throat were cutting,
I'd not come at you, now I have protested against it.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Why, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: 'Twas a foul storm tonight .

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: The lord Ferdinand's chamber, shook like an osier.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: 'Twas nothing but pure kindness in the devil,
To rock his own child. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: The reason why I would not suffer these
about my brother, is, because at midnight
I may with better privacy, convey
Julia's body, to her own lodging: oh, my conscience!
I would pray now: but the devil takes away my heart
For having any confidence in prayer.
About this hour, I appointed Bosola
To fetch the body: when he hath served my turn,
He dies. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Ha? 'twas the Cardinal's voice: I heard him name,
Bosola, and my death: listen, I hear ones footing.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Strangling is a very quiet death.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Nay then I see, I must stand upon my guard.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: What say 'To that? whisper, softly: do you agree to't?
So it must be done i'th' dark: the Cardinal
Would not for a thousand pounds, the doctor should see it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: My death is plotted; here's the consequence of murder.
"We value not desert, nor Christian breath,
When we know black deeds, must be cured with death.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Here stay sir, and be confident, I pray:
I'll fetch you a dark lantern. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Could I take him at his prayers,
There were hope of pardon.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Fall right my sword:
I'll not give thee so much leisure, as to pray.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O, I am gone: thou hast ended a long suit,
In a minute.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A most wretched thing,
That only have thy benefit in death,
To appear myself.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Where are you sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Very near my home: Bosola?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: O misfortune.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Smother thy pity, thou art dead else: Antonio?
The man I would have saved 'bove mine own life?
We are merely the stars tennis-balls (Struck, and banded
Which way please them) o good Antonio,
I'll whisper one thing in thy dying ear,
Shall make thy heart break quickly: thy fair Duchess
And two sweet children.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Their very names
Kindle a little life in me.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Are murdered!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Some men have wished to die.
At the hearing of sad tidings: I am glad
That I shall do't in sadness: I would not now
Wish my wounds balmed, nor healed: for I have no use
To put my life to: in all our quest of greatness;
(Like wanton boys, whose pastime is their care)
We follow after bubbles, blown in th'air.
Pleasure of life, what is't? only the good hours
Of an ague: merely a preparative to rest,
To endure vexation: I do not ask
The process of my death: only commend me
To Delio.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Break heart:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And let my son, fly the courts of princes,

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Thou seemest to have loved Antonio?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I brought him hither,
To have reconciled him to the Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I do not ask thee that:
Take him up, if thou tender thine own life,
And bear him, where the lady Julia
Was wont to lodge: o, my fate moves swift.
I have this Cardinal, in the forge already,
Now I'll bring him to th'hammer ▪ (Oh direful misprision:)
I will not imitate things glorious,
No more than base: I'll be mine own example.
On, on: and look thou represent, for silence,
The thing thou bearest. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena. V.
div.stage: Cardinal (With a book) Bosola, Pescara, Malateste, Rodorigo. Ferdinand, Delio, servant with Antonio's body.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: I am puzzled in a question about hell:
He says, in hell, there's one material fire,
And yet it shall not burn all men alike.
Lay him by: how tedious is a guilty conscience?
When I look into the fishponds, in my garden,
Methinks I see a thing, armed with a rake
That seems to strike at me: now? art thou come? thou lookest ghastly:
There sits in thy face, some great determination,
Mixed with some fear.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Thus it lightens into action:
I am come to kill thee.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Ha? help: our guard.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Thou art deceived:
They are out of thy howling.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Hold: and I will faithfully divide
Revenues with thee.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Thy prayers, and proffers
Are both unseasonable.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Raise the watch: we are betrayed.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: I have confined your flight:
I'll suffer your retreat to Julia's chamber,
But no further.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Help: we are betrayed.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Listen:

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: My dukedom, for rescue.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Fie upon his counterfeiting.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Why, 'tis nor the Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Yes, yes, 'tis he:
But I'll see him hanged, ere I'll go down to him.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Here's a plot upon me, I am assaulted: I am lost ▪
Unless some rescue.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.l: He doth this pretty well:
But it will not serve; to laugh me out of mine honour.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: The sword's at my throat:

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: You would not bawl so loud then.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Come, come: lets's go to bed: he told us thus much aforehand.

sp.speaker: Pesc.
sp.l: He wished you should not come at him: but believe't,
The accent of the voice sounds not in jest.
I'll down to him, howsoever, and with engines
Force ope the doors.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Let's follow him aloof,
And note how the Cardinal will laugh at him.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: There's for you first: 'cause you shall not unbarricade the door
To let in rescue. He kills the servant.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: What cause hast thou to pursue my life?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Look there:

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Antonio?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Slain by my hand unwittingly:
Pray, and be sudden: when thou killed'st thy sister,
Thou tookst from justice her most equal balance,
And left her naught but her sword.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: O mercy.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Now it seems thy greatness was only outward:
For thou fallest faster of thyself, than calamity
Can drive thee: I'll not waste longer time: there

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Thou hast hurt me:

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Again:

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Shall I die like a leveret
Without any resistance? help, help, help:
I am slain.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Th'alarum? give me a fresh horse:
Rally the vanguard: or the day is lost:
Yield, yield: I give you the honour of arms,
shake my sword over you, will you yield?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Help me, I am your brother.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: The devil?
My brother fight upon the adverse party? He wounds the Cardinal, and (In the scuffle) gives Bosola his death wound.
There flies your ransom.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: O justice:
I suffer now, for what hath former been:
"Sorrow is held the eldest child of sin.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Now you're brave follows:
Caesar's fortune was harder than Pompey's:
Caesar died in the arms of prosperity,
Pompey at the feet of disgrace: you both died in the field,
The pain's nothing: pain many times, is taken away, with
The apprehension of greater, (As the toothache with the sight
Of a barber, that comes to pull it out) there's philosophy for you.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Now my revenge is perfect: sink (Thou main cause
Of my undoing) the last part of my life,
Hath done me best service. He kills Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Give me some wet hay, I am broken winded,
I do account this world but a dog-kennel:
I will vault credit, and affect high pleasures,
Beyond death.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: He seems to come to himself, now he's so near the bottom .

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: My sister, o! my sister, there's the cause on't.
"Whether we fall by ambition, blood, or lust,
" like diamonds, we are cut with our own dust.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Thou hast thy payment too.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Yes, I hold my weary soul, in my teeth,
'Tis ready to part from me: I do glory
That thou, which stood'st like a huge pyramid
Begun upon a large, and ample base,
Shalt end in a little point a kind of nothing.

sp.speaker: Pes.
sp.l: How now (My lord?)

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: O sad disaster.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: How comes this?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Revenge, for the Duchess of Malfi, murdered
By th'aragonian brothers: for Antonio,
slain by his hand: for lustful Julia,
Poisoned by this man: and lastly, for myself,
(That was an actor in the main of all,
Much 'gainst mine own good nature, yet i'th' end
Neglected.)

sp.speaker: Pes.
sp.l: How now (My lord?)

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Look to my brother:
He gave us these large wounds, as we were struggling
Here i'th' rushes: and now, I pray, let me
Be laid by, and never thought of.

sp.speaker: Pes.
sp.l: How fatally (It seems) he did withstand,
His own rescue?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Thou wretched thing of blood,
How came Antonio by his death?

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: In a mist: I know not how,
Such a mistake, as I have often seen
In a play: o, I am gone,
We are only like dead walls, or vaulted graves,
That ruined, yields no echo: fare you well,
It may be pain: but no harm to me to die,
In so good a quarrel: o this gloomy world,
In what a shadow, or deep pit of darkness,
Doth (Womanish, and fearful) mankind live?
Let worthy minds, ne'er stagger in distrust
To suffer death, or shame for what is just,
Mine is another voyage.

sp.speaker: Pes.
sp.l: The noble Delio, as I came to th'palace,
Told me of Antonio's being here, and showed me
A pretty gentlemen his son and heir.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: O sir, you come too late.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: I heard so, and
Was armed for't ere I came: let us make noble use
Of this great ruin; and join all our force
To establish this young hopeful gentleman
In's mother's right. These wretched eminent things
Leave no more fame behind 'em, then should one
fall in a frost, and leave his print in snow,
As soon as the sun shines, it ever melts,
Both form, and matter: I have ever thought
Nature doth nothing so great, for great men,
As when she's pleased, to make them lords of truth:
"Integrity of life, is fame's best friend,
Which nobly (Beyond death) shall crown the end. Exeunt.
